Utah Code Annotated - Title 17 - Chapter 16a - County Officers and Employees Disclosure Act
*******************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-1 Citation of chapter.
---------------------------------------------------
This chapter may be cited as the "County Officers and Employees Disclosure Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-2 Purposes.
----------------------------------------
The purposes of this chapter are to establish standards of conduct for county officers and employees and to require these persons to disclose conflicts of interest between their public duties and their personal interests.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3 Definitions.
-------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(1)(a): "Appointed officer" means an individual appointed to:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(1)(a)(i): a statutory office or position; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(1)(a)(ii): a position of employment with a county, except a special employee.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(1)(b): "Appointed officer" includes an individual serving on a special, regular or full-time committee, agency, or board, regardless of whether the individual is compensated for the individual's services.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(1)(c): "Appointed officer" does not include an elected officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(2): "Assist" means to act, or offer or agree to act, in such a way as to help, represent, aid, advise, furnish information to, or otherwise provide assistance to a person or business entity, believing that such action is of help, aid, advice, or assistance to such person or business entity and with the intent to so assist such person or business entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(3): "Business entity" means a sole proprietorship, partnership, association, joint venture, corporation, firm, trust, foundation, or other organization or entity used in carrying on a business.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(4): "Compensation" means anything of economic value, however designated, which is paid, loaned, granted, given, donated or transferred to any person or business entity for or in consideration of personal services, materials, property, or any other thing whatsoever.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(5): "Elected officer" means an individual elected or appointed to an office in the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(6): "Governmental action" means an action on the part of a county including:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(6)(a): a decision, determination, finding, ruling, or order;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(6)(b): a grant, payment, award, license, contract, subcontract, transaction, decision, sanction, or approval; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(6)(c): the denial of, or failure to act upon, a matter described in Subsection (6)(a) or (b).
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(7): "Officer" means an appointed officer or an elected officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(8): "Special employee" means an individual hired on the basis of a contract to perform a special service for the county pursuant to an award of a contract following a public bid.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3(9): "Substantial interest" means the ownership, either legally or equitably, by an individual, the individual's spouse, and the individual's minor children, of at least 10% of the outstanding shares of a corporation or 10% interest in any other business entity.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-3.5 Statutory construction.
--------------------------------------------------------
The definition of appointed officer in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-4 Prohibited use of official position -- Exception.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-4(1): Except as provided in Subsection (3) or (5), it is an offense for an officer to:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-4(1)(a): disclose confidential information acquired by reason of the officer's official position or use that information to secure special privileges or exemptions for the officer or others;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-4(1)(b): use or attempt to use the officer's official position to secure special privileges for the officer or for others; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-4(1)(c): knowingly receive, accept, take, seek or solicit, directly or indirectly, any gift or loan for the officer or for another, if the gift or loan tends to influence the officer in the discharge of the officer's official duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-4(2): 17-16-6.5 This section does not apply to:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-4(2)(a): an occasional nonpecuniary gift having a value of less than $50;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-4(2)(b): an award publicly presented;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-4(2)(c): any bona fide loan made in the ordinary course of business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-4(2)(d): 17-16-6.5 political campaign contributions subject to Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-4(3): A member of a county legislative body who is also a member of the governing board of a provider of mental health or substance abuse services under contract with the county does not commit an offense under Subsection (1)(a) or (b) by discharging, in good faith, the duties and responsibilities of each position, if the county legislative body member does not participate in the process of selecting the mental health or substance abuse service provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-4(4): Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, a county or county official may encourage support from a public or private individual or institution, whether in financial contributions or by other means, on behalf of an organization or activity that benefits the community.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-4(5): 76-8-105 This section does not apply to an officer who engages in conduct that constitutes a violation of this section to the extent that the officer is chargeable, for the same conduct, under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5 Compensation for assistance in transaction involving county -- Public disclosure and filing required.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(1): An officer may not receive or agree to receive compensation for assisting a person or business entity in a transaction involving the county in which the officer is elected or appointed unless the officer:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(1)(a): files with the county legislative body a sworn statement disclosing the information described in Subsection (5);
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(1)(b): discloses in open meeting to the members of the body of which the officer is a member, immediately before the discussion, the information described in Subsection (5); and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(1)(c): for an officer who is an elected officer, files the sworn statement described in Subsection (1)(a) with the county clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(2): An officer shall file the sworn statement described in Subsection (1)(a) on or before the earlier of:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(2)(a): 10 days before the date on which the officer and the person or business entity being assisted enter into an agreement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(2)(b): 10 days before the date on which the officer receives compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(3): In accordance with Subsection (1)(c), an elected officer shall file the sworn statement with the county clerk on or before the earlier of the deadlines described in Subsections (2)(a) and (b).
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(4): A county clerk who receives the sworn statement described in Subsection (1)(a) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(4)(a): post a copy of the sworn statement on the county's website; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(4)(b): ensure that the sworn statement remains posted on the county's website until the elected officer leaves office.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(5): The sworn statement described in Subsection (1)(a) is public information and is available for examination by the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(6): The sworn statement and public disclosure described in Subsection (1) shall contain the following information:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(6)(a): the name and address of the officer;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(6)(b): the name and address of the person or business entity being or to be assisted, or in which the officer has a substantial interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-5(6)(c): a brief description of the transaction as to which service is rendered or is to be rendered and of the nature of the service performed or to be performed.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6 Interest in business entity regulated by county -- Disclosure.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(1): An officer under this part who is an officer, director, agent, or employee or the owner of a substantial interest in any business entity that is subject to the regulation of the county in which the officer is appointed or elected shall disclose the position held and the precise nature and value of the officer's interest:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(1)(a): upon first becoming appointed or elected; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(1)(b): during January of each year during which the officer continues to be an appointed or elected officer.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(2): An officer shall make the disclosure described in Subsection (1) in a sworn statement filed with:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(2)(a): the county legislative body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(2)(b): if the officer is an elected officer, the county clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(3): The commission shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(3)(a): report the substance of the sworn statement described in Subsection (2) to the members of the governing body; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(3)(b): provide a copy of the sworn statement described in Subsection (2) to the members of the governing body no later than 30 days after the day on which the commission receives the statement.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(4): A county clerk who receives the sworn statement described in Subsection (2) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(4)(a): post a copy of the sworn statement on the county's website; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(4)(b): ensure that the sworn statement remains posted on the county's website until the elected officer leaves office.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(5)(a): This section does not apply to instances where the value of the interest does not exceed $5,000.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-6(5)(b): A life insurance policy or an annuity may not be considered in determining the value of the interest.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-7 Interest in business entity doing business with county -- Disclosure.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-7(1): An officer under this part who is an officer, director, agent, or employee, or owner of a substantial interest in a business entity that does or anticipates doing business with the county in which the officer is appointed or elected shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-7(1)(a): publicly disclose the conflict of interest to the members of the body of which the officer is a member, immediately before a discussion by the body on matters relating to the business entity, the nature of the officer's interest in the business entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-7(1)(b): for an officer who is an elected officer, file a sworn statement describing the conflict of interest with the county clerk.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-7(2): The public disclosure described in Subsection (1)(a) shall be entered in the minutes of the meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-7(3): A county clerk who receives the sworn statement described in Subsection (1)(b) shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-7(3)(a): post a copy of the sworn statement on the county's website; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-7(3)(b): ensure that the sworn statement remains posted on the county's website until the elected officer leaves office.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-8 Investment creating conflict of interest with duties -- Disclosure.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
An officer who has a personal interest or investment that creates a potential or actual conflict between the officer's personal interests and the officer's public duties shall disclose the conflict in the manner described in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-9 Inducing officer to violate provisions prohibited.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
No person shall induce or seek to induce an officer to violate any of the provisions of this part.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-16a-10 Violation a misdemeanor -- Removal from office.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In addition to any penalty contained in any other provision of law, a person who knowingly and intentionally violates this part is guilty of a class A misdemeanor and shall be dismissed from employment or removed from office.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 17 - Chapter 18a - Powers and Duties of County and District Attorney
************************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
This chapter is known as "Powers and Duties of County and District Attorney."

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-102(1): 17-18a-301; 17-18a-301 "Attorney" means a county attorney described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-102(2): Part 7, Prosecution District "Prosecution district" means a district created under


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-201 County and district attorney duties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
The duties, functions, and responsibilities of a county attorney or district attorney, acting as a public prosecutor or as civil counsel, are as provided in this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-202 County attorney powers and functions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-202(1): Except within a county that is located in a prosecution district, the county attorney:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-202(1)(a): is a public prosecutor for the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-202(1)(b): shall perform each public prosecutor and civil counsel duty in accordance with this chapter or as otherwise required by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-202(2): In a county that is located within a prosecution district, the county attorney:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-202(2)(a): is the civil counsel for the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-202(2)(b): shall perform each civil counsel duty in the county or prosecution district in accordance with this chapter or as otherwise required by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203 District attorney powers and functions.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
In a county that is located within a prosecution district, the district attorney:Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203(1): is a public prosecutor for the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203(2): shall perform each public prosecutor duty in accordance with this chapter or as otherwise required by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5 District attorney data collection -- Report.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(1): In this section, "prosecution personnel" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(1)(a): investigators;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(1)(b): prosecutors;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(1)(c): support staff; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(1)(d): other individuals paid for their work on the case.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(2): The district attorney in a county of the first class shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(2)(a): track the time spent by prosecution personnel on each criminal case, calculated in quarter of an hour increments, by the offense classification; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(2)(b): provide a written report to the Law Enforcement and Criminal Justice Interim Committee by November 1, annually.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3): The annual report required in Subsection (2)(b) shall include the following information, organized by the offense classification, for the cases that were active during the reporting period:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(a): the total number of hours, calculated in quarter of an hour increments, worked on the cases by prosecution personnel;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(b): the average amount of taxpayer dollars spent per case, as calculated by the hours worked and the salary of the prosecution personnel who worked on the case;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(c): the cumulative total hours worked and the number of cases, categorized by the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(c)(i): cases that were dismissed prior to the filing of charges;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(c)(ii): cases that were dismissed after charges were filed;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(c)(iii): cases in which a plea agreement was reached by the parties prior to the preliminary hearing;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(c)(iv): cases that were dismissed by the court after the preliminary hearing;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(c)(v): cases in which a plea agreement was reached by the parties after the preliminary hearing;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(c)(vi): cases that resulted in a court ruling in favor of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(c)(vii): cases that resulted in a court ruling in favor of the defense;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(d): the average number of days between:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(d)(i): the filing of criminal charges; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(d)(ii): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(d)(ii)(A): the delivery of discovery information, including witness statements;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(d)(ii)(B): the preliminary hearing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(d)(ii)(C): the first day of trial; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-203.5(3)(e): the average number of attorneys assigned to each case.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-401 Public prosecutor powers and duties.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
An attorney who serves as a public prosecutor shall:Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-401(1): 10-3-928 except for a prosecution undertaken by a city attorney under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-401(2): conduct, on behalf of the county, all prosecutions for a public offense in violation of a county criminal ordinance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-401(3): perform all other duties and responsibilities as required by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402 Pretrial responsibilities.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(1): (1)(a)(i)(B)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(1)(a): A public prosecutor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(1)(a)(i): institute proceedings before the proper court:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(1)(a)(i)(A): for the arrest of a person charged with a public offense; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(1)(a)(i)(B): if the prosecutor has probable cause to believe that a public offense has been committed and a grand jury has been convened by a court;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(1)(a)(ii): draw all indictments and information for offenses against:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(1)(a)(ii)(A): the laws of the state occurring within the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(1)(a)(ii)(B): the criminal ordinances of the county;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(1)(a)(iii): cause all persons under indictment or informed against to be speedily arraigned for crimes charged; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(1)(a)(iv): issue subpoenas for all witnesses for the state or for the county in the prosecution of a criminal ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(1)(b): (1)(a)(i)(B) A public prosecutor described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(1)(b)(i): assist and attend the deliberations of the grand jury; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(1)(b)(ii): prepare all necessary indictments and arrange for the subpoena of witnesses to appear before the grand jury.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(2): (2)(b)(i) The public prosecutor may:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(2)(a): examine as to the sufficiency of an appearance bond that may be tendered to the court; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(2)(b): (2)(b)(i) upon a court order:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(2)(b)(i): institute proceedings for the recovery upon forfeiture of a bond running to the state or county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(2)(b)(ii): (2)(b)(i) enforce the collection of a bond described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-402(3): The public prosecutor is authorized to grant transactional immunity to a witness for violation of a state statute or county criminal ordinance.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-403 Appeal.
----------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-403(1): A public prosecutor shall assist and cooperate, as required by the attorney general, in a case that may be appealed to the Court of Appeals or Utah Supreme Court regarding a criminal violation of state statute.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-403(2): A public prosecutor shall appear and prosecute all appeals, in the appropriate court, for a crime charged as a misdemeanor in district court or as a violation of a county criminal ordinance.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-404 Juvenile proceedings.
------------------------------------------------------
For a proceeding involving an offense committed by a minor as defined in SectionUtah Code Annotated § 17-18a-404(1): Title 80, Chapter 6, Juvenile Justice review cases in accordance with
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-404(2): appear and prosecute for the state in the juvenile court of the county.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-405 Civil responsibilities of public prosecutors.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A public prosecutor may act as legal counsel to the state, county, government agency, or government entity regarding the following matters of civil law:Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-405(1): bail bond forfeiture actions;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-405(2): Title 77, Chapter 11b, Forfeiture of Seized Property actions for the forfeiture of property or contraband, as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-405(3): civil actions incidental to or appropriate to supplement a public prosecutor's duties, including an injunction, a habeas corpus, a declaratory action, or an extraordinary writ action, in which the interests of the state may be affected; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-405(4): any other civil duties related to criminal prosecution that are otherwise provided by statute.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-501 Duties as civil counsel.
---------------------------------------------------------
The attorney shall:Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-501(1): appear in, prosecute, and defend each civil action in which the county is a party;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-501(2): prosecute, either directly or through a private contract for debt collection, each action for the recovery of debts, fines, penalties, and forfeitures accruing to the county;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-501(3): prosecute each appeal regarding a civil counsel's duties or functions in which the county is a party;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-501(4): act as the civil legal advisor to the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-501(5): attend the meetings and hearings of the county legislative body as necessary.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-502 Civil violation of county ordinance.
---------------------------------------------------------------------
The civil counsel shall enforce and prosecute, in the appropriate court, civil violations of a county ordinance.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-503 Legal opinions.
------------------------------------------------
The civil counsel shall prepare a legal opinion in writing to a county officer on matters relating to the duties of the respective officer's office.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-504 Review and advise as to form.
--------------------------------------------------------------
The civil counsel shall review and advise as to form and legality each county contract, ordinance, regulation, real estate document, conveyance, and legal document.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-505 Escheats to the state.
-------------------------------------------------------
The civil counsel shall:Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-505(1): assist in determining what estate or property located within the county escheates or reverts to the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-505(2): provide assistance to the county assessor and the state auditor in discovering and recovering an escheat.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506 Correctional facility telephone service contracts -- Approval by civil counsel -- Required rates.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(1): 17-18a-102; 77-16b-102 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(1)(a): 17-18a-102 "Civil counsel" means the attorney, as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(1)(b): 77-16b-102 "Correctional facility" means the same as that term is defined in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(1)(d): "Inmate" means an individual who is committed to the custody of or housed in a correctional facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(1)(e): "Inmate telephone rate" means any amount a correctional facility or a service provider charges an inmate for use of a correctional facility telephone service, including each per-minute rate or surcharge for:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(1)(e)(i): a collect call, a prepaid phone card, or any other method by which a correctional facility allows an inmate to access a correctional facility telephone service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(1)(e)(ii): a local or a long-distance phone call.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(1)(f): "Service provider" means a public entity or a private entity that provides a correctional facility telephone service.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(2): (2)(b); (3)(a)

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(2)(b): A correctional facility or other state entity may not enter into or renew a contract for a correctional facility telephone service, unless the contract is approved by the civil counsel.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(2)(c): (2)(b); (3)(a) To obtain approval of a contract described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(2)(c)(ii): (3)(a) documentation that the correctional facility or other state entity has confirmed that:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(2)(c)(ii)(A): (3)(a) the provisions of the contract, other than the rates described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(2)(c)(ii)(B): the contract provides for adequate services that meet the needs of the correctional facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(2)(c)(iii): any additional information the civil counsel requires to analyze the contract.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(3): (2)(b); (3)(a)

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(3)(a)(i): each inmate telephone rate for interstate calls provided in the contract exceeds the corresponding inmate telephone service monetary cap per-use rate established and published by the Federal Communications Commission; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(3)(a)(ii): each inmate telephone rate for intrastate calls provided in the contract exceeds the greater of:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(3)(a)(ii)(A): 25% higher than the corresponding inmate telephone service monetary cap per-use rate established and published by the Federal Communications Commission; or

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(3)(b): (3)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(3)(b)(i): (3)(a) After receiving and reviewing the proposed contract and additional information, the civil counsel shall approve the contract if the proposed contract meets the requirements described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-506(3)(b)(ii): The civil counsel shall inform the correctional facility or other state entity of the civil counsel's determination.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-601 Assistance to the attorney general.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-601(1): (1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-601(1)(a): (1)(b) The attorney shall appear and assist the attorney general in criminal and civil legal matters involving the state if:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-601(1)(a)(i): (1)(b) except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-601(1)(a)(ii): the attorney is required by law to provide assistance.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-601(1)(b): The attorney is not required to provide, if requested, the attorney general assistance if the attorney's assistance would:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-601(1)(b)(i): interfere with the attorney's duties and responsibilities to the county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-601(1)(b)(ii): create a conflict of interest.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-601(1)(c): The attorney shall cooperate with the attorney general in an investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-601(2): The attorney general shall assist the attorney with a criminal prosecution if a court:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-601(2)(a): finds that the attorney is unable to satisfactorily and adequately perform the duties of prosecuting a criminal case; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-601(2)(b): recommends that the attorney seek additional legal assistance.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-602 Deputy attorneys.
--------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-602(1): The attorney may employ a deputy attorney to perform the duties of public prosecutor or civil counsel.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-602(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-602(2)(a): Subject to the approval of the county attorney, the district attorney may cross deputize a county deputy attorney as a deputy district attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-602(2)(b): Subject to the approval of the district attorney, the county attorney may cross deputize a deputy district attorney as a deputy county attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-602(3): The county attorney may specially deputize, for a limited time or limited purpose, an attorney licensed to practice law in the state and in good standing with the Utah State Bar as a deputy to assist in any public prosecutor or civil counsel duties specified in the special deputization.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-603 Legislative functions.
-------------------------------------------------------
The attorney:Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-603(1): may review a state statute;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-603(2): shall review each county ordinance;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-603(3): shall call to the attention of the state Legislature or the county legislative body any defect in the operation of the law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-603(4): shall suggest and assist in presenting an amendment to correct the defect.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-604 Other duties.
----------------------------------------------
The attorney shall perform each duty and responsibility of public prosecutor and civil counsel as provided by statute or ordinance.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-605 Prohibited acts.
-------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-605(1): Within the state, the attorney may not consult with or otherwise represent a person charged with a crime, misdemeanor, or breach of a criminal statute or ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-605(2): A public prosecutor may not prosecute or dismiss in the name of the state a case in which the public prosecutor has previously acted as legal counsel for the accused.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-605(3): A public prosecutor may not after the filing of an indictment or information and without the consent of the court:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-605(3)(a): compromise a prosecution; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-605(3)(b): enter a plea of nolle prosequi.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-701 Creation of a prosecution district.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
A county legislative body may, by ordinance, create a countywide prosecution district.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-801 Public prosecutor's ethical duties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
An attorney exercising public prosecutor duties under this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-801(1): is a lawyer representing an organization as a client under the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 1.13;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-801(2): represents the state as an organizational client;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-801(3): is considered the representative of the state; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-801(4): is empowered to make commitments for and decisions on behalf of the state.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-802 Representation by civil counsel -- County is client.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-802(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-802(1)(a): An attorney acting as civil counsel under this chapter represents an organization as a client in accordance with Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 1.13.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-802(1)(b): (1)(a) The county is the client organization described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-802(2): The attorney:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-802(2)(a): does not represent a county commission, county agency, county board, county council, county officer, or county employee;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-802(2)(b): counsels with the county regarding civil matters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-802(2)(c): receives direction from the county through the county elected officers in accordance with the officers' duties and powers in accordance with law.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-802(3): (2)(a) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-802(3)(a): with the approval of the county executive; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-802(3)(b): if permitted by law and the Rules of Professional Conduct.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-18a-803 License suspended -- Vacancy.
--------------------------------------------------------------
If the attorney is suspended or disbarred from the practice of law in the state, the attorney's office is vacant immediately upon suspension or disbarment.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 17 - Chapter 19a - County Auditor
*************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(1): (1)(a) "Account" or "accounting" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(1)(a): the systematic recording, classification, or summarizing of a financial transaction or event; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(1)(b): (1)(a) the interpretation or presentation of the result of an action described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(2)(a): "Accounting services" means the creation, modification, or deletion of transactions and records in a financial accounting system, including the preparation of a county's annual financial report.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(2)(b): "Accounting services" does not include the creation of a purchase order.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(3): "Audit" or "auditing" means an examination that is a formal analysis of a county account or county financial record:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(3)(a): to verify accuracy, completeness, or compliance with an internal control;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(3)(b): to give a fair presentation of a county's financial status; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(3)(c): that conforms to the uniform classification of accounts established by the state auditor.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(4): "Book" means a financial record of the county, regardless of a record's format.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(5): Chapter 36, Uniform Fiscal Procedures Act for Counties; (5)(b)(i); (ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(5)(a): Chapter 36, Uniform Fiscal Procedures Act for Counties "Budget" or "budgeting" means the preparation or presentation of a proposed or tentative budget as provided in
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(5)(b): (5)(b)(i); (ii) "Budget" or "budgeting" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(5)(b)(i): a revenue projection;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(5)(b)(ii): a budget request compilation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(5)(b)(iii): (5)(b)(i); (ii) the performance of an activity described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(6)(a): "Claim" means under the color of law:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(6)(a)(i): a demand presented for money or damages; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(6)(a)(ii): a cause of action presented for money or damages.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(6)(b): "Claim" does not mean a routine, uncontested, or regular payment, including a bill, purchase, or payroll.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(7): 17-53-101; 17-19a-202(6)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(7)(a): 17-53-101 "County auditor" means the county officer elected as the county auditor under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(7)(b): 17-19a-202(6) "County auditor" includes a person given the title of county controller under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(8): "County executive" means the elected chief executive officer of a county.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(9): "Performance audit" means an assessment of whether a county office, officer, department, division, court, or entity, or any related county program is:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(9)(a): managing public resources and exercising authority in compliance with law and policy;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(9)(b): achieving objectives and desired outcomes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-102(9)(c): providing services effectively, efficiently, economically, ethically, and equitably.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-202 Duties and services.
-----------------------------------------------------
A county auditor shall perform:Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-202(1): 17-19a-205 in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-202(2): an auditing duty or service described in this chapter or otherwise required by law; and

Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206 Performance audit services.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(1): In a county of the first class, the county auditor shall conduct a performance audit:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(1)(a): as the county auditor deems appropriate, taking into account:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(1)(a)(i): the standards of the profession;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(1)(a)(ii): the county auditor's professional judgment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(1)(a)(iii): the county auditor's assessment of risk and materiality; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(1)(b): as requested and engaged by the county legislative body or county executive, in accordance with the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(1)(b)(i): the county legislative body or county executive shall establish the goals and nature of the performance audit;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(1)(b)(ii): the county auditor shall conduct the audit in a manner consistent with the county auditor's professional judgment and statutory duties; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(1)(b)(iii): the county legislative body or county executive and the county auditor shall agree upon the prioritization and timing of the performance audit, with terms that are consistent with the county auditor's statutory duties and available resources.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(2)(a): In a county of the second through sixth class, the county auditor shall conduct a performance audit under the direction and supervision of the county legislative body or county executive.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(2)(b): (2)(a) The county legislative body or county executive shall establish the goals and nature of a performance audit conducted under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(3): A performance audit conducted under this section may include an assessment of the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(3)(a): the honesty and integrity of financial and other affairs;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(3)(b): the accuracy and reliability of financial and management reports;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(3)(c): the adequacy of financial controls to safeguard public funds;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(3)(d): the management and staff adherence to statute, ordinance, policies, and legislative intent;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(3)(e): the economy, efficiency, and effectiveness of operational performance;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(3)(f): the accomplishment of intended objectives; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-206(3)(g): whether management, financial, and information systems are adequate and effective.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-401 County auditor investigative powers -- Report of findings.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-401(1): (1)(a)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-401(1)(a): A county auditor:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-401(1)(a)(i): may conduct an investigation of an issue or action associated with or related to the auditor's statutory duties, including investigating a book or account of a county office, officer, department, division, court, or entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-401(1)(a)(ii): may not conduct an investigation of an issue or action that is not associated with or related to the auditor's statutory duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-401(1)(b): (1)(a)(i) A county officer, employee, or other county administrative entity shall grant the county auditor complete and free access to a book requested by the county auditor in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-401(1)(c): A county auditor, with the assistance of the county or district attorney, may:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-401(1)(c)(i): administer an oath or affirmation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-401(1)(c)(ii): issue an administrative subpoena for a witness or document necessary to the performance of the auditor's statutory duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-401(2): If the county auditor, after a complete investigation, finds that a book or account of a county office, officer, department, division, court, or entity is not kept in accordance to law, or that an office, officer, department, division, court, or entity has made an incorrect or improper financial report, the county auditor shall prepare a report of the auditor's findings and submit a copy of the report to the county executive.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-19a-401(3): If a county auditor, after a complete investigation, finds that a justice court judge has not kept a book or account according to law, or that the justice court judge has made an incorrect or improper financial report, the auditor shall prepare a report of the auditor's findings and submit a copy of the report to the state court administrator, the county executive, and the county legislative body.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 17 - Chapter 20 - County Clerk
**********************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1 County clerk -- District court clerk duties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------
The county clerk is the clerk of the legislative body of the county.  The clerk shall act as clerk of the district court in secondary counties of the state district court administrative system and those counties not in the system, and shall perform the duties listed in Section

Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.5 Clerk of county legislative body.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
The county clerk is the clerk of the county legislative body.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7 Clerk's duties.
-----------------------------------------------
The clerk shall:Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7(1): record all proceedings of the county legislative body;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7(2): make full entries of all resolutions and decisions of the county legislative body on all questions concerning the county;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7(3): record the vote of each member on any question upon which there is a division;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7(4): prepare and certify duplicate lists of all claims, showing the amount and date of each claim or order and the date of the allowance or rejection of the claim, which lists shall be countersigned by the county executive;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7(5): (4) deliver to and leave with the county auditor one of the lists referred to in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7(6): file and preserve the reports of the county officers to the county legislative body;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7(7): preserve and file all accounts acted upon by the county legislative body, except such as are necessarily kept by the auditor;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7(8): preserve and file all petitions and applications for franchises, and record the action of the county legislative body on them;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7(9): authenticate with the clerk's signature and the seal of the county the proceedings of the county legislative body if the proceedings are ordered published;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7(10): authenticate with the clerk's signature and the seal of the county all ordinances or laws passed by the county legislative body, and record them at length in the ordinance book;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7(11): record all orders levying taxes;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7(12): keep at the clerk's office all county books, records, and accounts that the clerk is required by law to keep and keep them open at all times during regular business hours for public inspection; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-1.7(13): perform all other duties required by law or by any rule or order of the county legislative body.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-3 County clerk -- Record of notaries public.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
The county clerk of each county receiving certifications of notaries public from the lieutenant governor shall keep and maintain an indexed record for that purpose, showing the names of all persons holding notarial commissions, with the dates of issuance and expiration.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-4 Duties of county clerk.
-----------------------------------------------------
A county clerk shall:Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-4(1): establish policies to issue all marriage licenses and keep a register of marriages as provided by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-4(2): establish policies to ensure that the county clerk, or a designee of the county clerk who is willing, is available during business hours to solemnize a legal marriage for which a marriage license has been issued;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-4(3): execute under the clerk's seal and in the name of and for the county, all deeds and conveyances of all real estate conveyed by the county;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-4(4): take and certify acknowledgments and administer oaths;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-4(5): keep a fee book as provided by law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-4(6): take charge of and safely keep the seal of the county, and keep other records and perform other duties as may be prescribed by law.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-5 Report of election and appointment of officers.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Within 10 days after the day on which a county clerk issues a certificate of election or a certificate of appointment made to fill vacancies in elective county offices, the county clerk shall notify the lieutenant governor of the following:Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-5(1): the name of the county;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-5(2): the name of the county office to which the individual was elected or appointed;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-5(3): the date of the election or appointment of the individual;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-5(4): the date of the expiration of the term for which the individual was elected or appointed;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-5(5): the date of the certificate of election or appointment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-20-5(6): the date of the qualification of the individual elected or appointed.


Utah Code Annotated - Title 17 - Chapter 21 - Recorder
******************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-1 Recorder -- Document custody responsibility -- Compliance with rules made by the County Recorder Standards Board -- Compliance with county appeal authority.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The county recorder:Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-1(1): is custodian of all recorded documents and records required by law to be recorded;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-1(2): 63C-30-202 shall comply with rules made by the County Recorder Standards Board under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-1(2)(a): the protection of recorded documents and records in the county recorder's custody;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-1(2)(b): the electronic submission of plats, records, and other documents to the county recorder's office;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-1(2)(c): the protection of privacy interests in the case of documents and records in the county recorder's custody; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-1(2)(d): the formatting, recording, and redaction of documents and records in the county recorder's custody;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-1(3): 17-50-340 shall comply with the appeal authority established by the county legislative body in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-1(4): 63C-30-202 may adopt policies and procedures governing the office of the county recorder that do not conflict with this chapter or rules made by the County Recorder Standards Board under Section


Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-2 Seal.
-----------------------------------
The county recorder shall have a seal, to be furnished by the county legislative body, the impression of which shall contain the following words: "State of Utah, County Recorder," together with the name of the county in which the same is to be used.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-3 Original documents or copies of original documents to be kept by the county.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
After accepting a document for recording, receiving the fees for recording it, and completing recording procedures, the recorder shall, only if required by statute, keep the original document or a copy of the original document as a public record in a form sufficient to meet the requirements of this chapter.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-4 Certified copies.
-----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-4(1): The county recorder may make and furnish certified photographic copies of any of the records in the office to an interested person who pays the applicable fees and charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-4(2): The county recorder shall supply certified copies of any of the records to the county officer for the officer's official use without the payment of any fee.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-5 Receipts for documents received for record.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Upon recording an instrument, the recorder shall, if requested, give a receipt to a person presenting an instrument for recording.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6 General duties of recorder -- Records and indexes.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1): 70D-1-102; 70D-1-102 Each recorder shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(a): keep an entry record, in which the recorder shall, upon acceptance and recording of any instrument, enter the instrument in the order of its recording, the names of the parties to the instrument, its date, the hour, the day of the month and the year of recording, and a brief description, and endorse upon each instrument a number corresponding with the number of the entry;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(b): keep a grantors' index, in which the recorder shall index deeds and final judgments or decrees partitioning or affecting the title to or possession of real property, which shall show the entry number of the instrument, the name of each grantor in alphabetical order, the name of the grantee, the date of the instrument, the time of recording, the kind of instrument, the book and page, and a brief description;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(c): keep a grantees' index, in which the recorder shall index deeds and final judgments or decrees partitioning or affecting the title to or possession of real property, which shall show the entry number of the instrument, the name of each grantee in alphabetical order, the name of the grantor, the date of the instrument, the time of recording, the kind of instrument, the book and page, and a brief description;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(d): keep a mortgagors' index, in which the recorder shall enter all mortgages, deeds of trust, liens, and other instruments in the nature of an encumbrance upon real estate, which shall show the entry number of the instrument, the name of each mortgagor, debtor, or person charged with the encumbrance in alphabetical order, the name of the mortgagee, lien holder, creditor, or claimant, the date of the instrument, the time of recording, the instrument, consideration, the book and page, and a brief description;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(e): keep a mortgagees' index, in which the recorder shall enter all mortgages, deeds of trust, liens, and other instruments in the nature of an encumbrance upon real estate, which shall show the entry number of the instrument, the name of each mortgagee, lien holder, creditor, or claimant, in alphabetical order, the name of the mortgagor or person charged with the encumbrance, the date of the instrument, the time of recording, the kind of instrument, the consideration, the book and page, and a brief description;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(f): subject to Subsection (4), keep a tract index, which shall show by description every instrument recorded, the date and the kind of instrument, the time of recording, and the book and page and entry number;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(g): keep an index of recorded maps, plats, and subdivisions;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(h): keep an index of powers of attorney showing the date and time of recording, the book, the page, and the entry number;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(i): keep a miscellaneous index, in which the recorder shall enter all instruments of a miscellaneous character not otherwise provided for in this section, showing the date of recording, the book, the page, the entry number, the kind of instrument, from, to, and the parties;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(j): keep an index of judgments showing the judgment debtors, the judgment creditors, the amount of judgment, the date and time of recording, the satisfaction, and the book, the page, and the entry number;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(k): keep a general recording index in which the recorder shall index all executions and writs of attachment, and any other instruments not required by law to be spread upon the records, and in separate columns the recorder shall enter the names of the plaintiffs in the execution and the names of the defendants in the execution;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(l): keep an index of water right numbers that are included on an instrument recorded on or after May 13, 2014, showing the date and time of recording, the book and the page or the entry number, and the kind of instrument; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(m): 70D-1-102; 70D-1-102 beginning January 1, 2025:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(m)(i): 70D-1-102 maintain a system that allows a property owner to receive, upon the property owner's election, an electronic notice when the county recorder records a deed or mortgage, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(1)(m)(ii): 70D-1-102 if a property owner elects to receive electronic notice as described in Subsection (1)(m)(i), within 30 days after the day on which the county recorder records a deed or a mortgage as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(2): Upon request, a county recorder may provide the notice described in Subsection (1)(m)(ii) to a property owner by a means other than electronic.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(3): 59-2-1317 Subsection (1)(m) applies only to real property for which the county treasurer provides a tax notice described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(4): The recorder shall alphabetically arrange the indexes required by this section and keep a reverse index.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5): 17-21-20; 57-3-105
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5)(a): The tract index required by Subsection (1)(f) shall be kept so that it shows a true chain of title to each tract or parcel, together with each encumbrance on the tract or parcel, according to the records of the office.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5)(b): 17-21-20; 57-3-105 A recorder shall abstract an instrument in the tract index unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5)(b)(i): 17-21-20; 57-3-105 the instrument is required to contain a legal description under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5)(b)(ii): the instrument contains errors, omissions, or defects to the extent that the tract or parcel to which the instrument relates cannot be determined.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5)(c): If a recorder abstracts an instrument in the tract index or another index required by this section, the recorder may:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5)(c)(i): use a tax parcel number;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5)(c)(ii): use a site address;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5)(c)(iii): reference to other instruments of record recited on the instrument; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5)(c)(iv): reference another instrument that is recorded concurrently with the instrument.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5)(d): A recorder is not required to go beyond the face of an instrument to determine the tract or parcel to which an instrument may relate.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5)(e): A person may not bring an action against a recorder for injuries or damages suffered as a result of information contained in an instrument recorded in a tract index or other index that is required by this section despite errors, omissions, or defects in the instrument.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5)(f): The fact that a recorded instrument described in Subsection (3)(e) is included in the tract index does not cure a failure to give public notice caused by an error, omission, or defect.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(5)(g): A document that is indexed in all or part of the indexes required by this section shall give constructive notice.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-6(6): Nothing in this section prevents the recorder from using a single name index if that index includes all of the indexes required by this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-9 Indexing of deeds and other instruments.
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Deeds and other instruments affecting real estate made by a United States marshal, a sheriff, master in chancery, special commissioner, executor, administrator, guardian, trustee, or other person acting in behalf of another shall be indexed in the name of the person whose land is sold or affected as grantor.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-10 Judgments affecting real estate.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-10(1): A county recorder shall record for real property, any part of which is located in the county:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-10(1)(a): a judgment affecting the real property;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-10(1)(b): a release, assignment, renewal, or extension of a judgment lien affecting the real property; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-10(1)(c): a certified copy of a final judgment or decree partitioning or affecting the title or possession of the real property.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-11 Notice given by recording.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-11(1): Each certified copy from the time of recording gives notice to all persons of the contents of the recorded document.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-11(2): Subsequent purchasers, mortgagees, and lien holders purchase and encumber with the same notice and effect as if the certified copy was the original document.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-14 Military records -- Evidence.
------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-14(1): Upon presentation, the county recorder shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-14(1)(a): record, free of charge, discharges from the military, naval, or marine service of the United States, and any and all orders, citations, and decorations of honor relating to a person while the person was in the military, naval, or marine service of the United States; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-14(1)(b): furnish, free of charge, certified copies of any of those records to the person to whom they relate and to the father, mother, brothers, sisters, or any lineal descendant of that person.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-14(2): Those certified copies may be read in evidence with the same effect as the original in any action or proceeding before any court, commission, or other tribunal in this state.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-16 Acknowledgments and administrations of oaths.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
County recorders may take and certify acknowledgments and administer oaths.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-18 Fees must be paid in advance.
------------------------------------------------------------
The  recorder may not record any instrument, furnish any copies, or provide any service connected with the office, until the fees prescribed by law have been paid or have been authorized to be paid electronically.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-18.5(1)(e): 17-21-12.5 for redacting personal information pursuant to Section

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-21 Ownership plats -- Use of geographic information systems or computer systems.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-21(1): The county recorder shall prepare and keep ownership plats drawn to a convenient scale, which show the record owners of each tract of land in the county, together with the dimensions of the tract.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-21(2): The county recorder may not be required to:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-21(2)(a): show ownership of timeshare units or timeshare estates on ownership plats; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-21(2)(b): show lot or unit ownership on subdivisions or condominium plats or other ownership plats if that information is available through computer systems or other indexes.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-21(3): Nothing in this chapter precludes the use of geographic information systems or computer systems by the recorder if the systems include all of the information required by this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-22 Annual revision -- Reporting changes in ownership to county assessors -- Use of geographic information systems or computer systems.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-22(1): The county recorder shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-22(1)(a): each year, prepare copies of ownership plats and descriptions, showing record owners at noon on January 1;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-22(1)(b): on or before January 30 of each year, transmit the copies to the county assessor;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-22(1)(c): report all changes in recorded ownership of real property made during the first seven months of each calendar year to the county assessor not later than August 15 of that year;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-22(1)(d): for the remainder of the calendar year, report the changes in the ownership of real property that are recorded in the county recorder's office each month on or before the 15th day of the month following the month in which the changes were recorded;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-22(1)(e): transmit the changes of ownership on appropriate forms that show the current owner's name and a full legal description of the property conveyed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-22(1)(f): where only a part of the grantor's property is conveyed, transmit an additional form showing a full legal description of the portion retained.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21-22(2): Nothing in this chapter precludes the use of geographic information systems or computer systems by the recorder if the systems include all of the information required by this section.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 17 - Chapter 21a - Uniform Real Property Electronic Recording Act
*********************************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-101 Title.
---------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-101(1): This chapter is known as the "Uniform Real Property Electronic Recording Act."
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-101(2): This part is known as "General Provisions."


Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-102 Definitions.
---------------------------------------------
As used in this chapter:Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-102(1): 17-21a-302 "Commission" means the Utah Electronic Recording Commission established in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-102(2): "Document" means information that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-102(2)(a): inscribed on a tangible medium or that is stored in an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-102(2)(b): eligible to be recorded in the land records maintained by the county recorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-102(3): "Electronic" means relating to technology having electrical, digital, magnetic, wireless, optical, electromagnetic, or similar capabilities.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-102(4): "Electronic document" means a document that is received by the county recorder in an electronic form.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-102(5): "Electronic signature" means an electronic sound, symbol, or process attached to or logically associated with a document and executed or adopted by a person with the intent to sign the document.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-102(6): "Person" means an individual, corporation, business trust, estate, trust, partnership, limited liability company, association, joint venture, public corporation, government, or governmental subdivision, agency, or instrumentality, or any other legal or commercial entity.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-102(7): "State" means a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands, or any territory or insular possession subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-201 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as "Electronic Documents."

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-202 Validity of electronic documents.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-202(1): If a law requires, as a condition for recording, that a document be an original, be on paper or another tangible medium, or be in writing, the requirement is satisfied by an electronic document satisfying this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-202(2): If a law requires, as a condition for recording, that a document be signed, the requirement is satisfied by an electronic signature.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-202(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-202(3)(a): A requirement that a document or a signature associated with a document be notarized, acknowledged, verified, witnessed, or made under oath is satisfied if the electronic signature of the person authorized to perform that act, and all other information required to be included, is attached to or logically associated with the document or signature.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-202(3)(b): A physical or electronic image of a stamp, impression, or seal need not accompany an electronic signature.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-203 Recording of documents.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-203(1): As used in this section, "paper document" means a document that is received by the county recorder in a form that is not electronic.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-203(2): 17-21a-301 A county recorder:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-203(2)(a): 17-21a-301 who implements any of the functions listed in this section shall do so in compliance with standards established by the Utah Electronic Recording Commission created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-203(2)(b): may receive, index, store, archive, and transmit electronic documents;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-203(2)(c): may provide for access to, and for search and retrieval of, documents and information by electronic means;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-203(2)(d): who accepts electronic documents for recording shall continue to accept paper documents as authorized by state law and shall place entries for both types of documents in the same index;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-203(2)(e): may convert paper documents accepted for recording into electronic form;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-203(2)(f): may convert into electronic form information recorded before the county recorder began to record electronic documents;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-203(2)(g): may accept electronically any fee that the county recorder is authorized to collect; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-203(2)(h): may agree with other officials of a state or a political subdivision thereof, or of the United States, on procedures or processes to facilitate the electronic satisfaction of prior approvals and conditions precedent to recording and the electronic payment of fees.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-401 Title.
---------------------------------------
This part is known as "Relationship to Other Laws."

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-402 Uniformity of application and construction.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
In applying and construing this uniform act, consideration must be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among states that enact it.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-21a-403 Relation to Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
This chapter modifies, limits, and supersedes the federal Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act (15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001, et seq.) but does not modify, limit, or supersede Section 101(c) of that act (15 U.S.C. Sec. 7001(c)) or authorize electronic delivery of any of the notices described in Section 103(b) of that act (15 U.S.C. Sec. 7003(b)).

Utah Code Annotated - Title 17 - Chapter 22 - Sheriff
*****************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-1 "Process," "notice," defined.
-----------------------------------------------------------
"Process" as used in this chapter includes all writs, warrants, summonses and orders of the courts of justice or judicial officers. "Notice" includes all papers and orders, except process, required to be served in any proceeding before any court, board, commission or officer, or when required by law to be served independently of such proceedings.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2 Sheriff -- General duties.
--------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1): 17-53-311; 53-10-404; 80-1-102; 53-22-103 The sheriff shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(a): preserve the peace;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(b): make all lawful arrests;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(c): attend in person or by deputy the Supreme Court and the Court of Appeals when required or when the court is held within his county, all courts of record, and court commissioner and referee sessions held within his county, obey their lawful orders and directions, and comply with the court security rule, Rule 3-414, of the Utah Code of Judicial Administration;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(d): upon request of the juvenile court, aid the court in maintaining order during hearings and transport a minor to and from youth corrections facilities, other institutions, or other designated places;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(e): attend county justice courts if the judge finds that the matter before the court requires the sheriff's attendance for security, transportation, and escort of jail prisoners in his custody, or for the custody of jurors;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(f): command the aid of as many inhabitants of the sheriff's county as the sheriff considers necessary in the execution of these duties;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(g): take charge of and keep the county jail and the jail prisoners;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(h): receive and safely keep all persons committed to the sheriff's custody, file and preserve the commitments of those persons in custody, and record the name, age, place of birth, and description of each person committed;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(i): release on the record all attachments of real property when the attachment the sheriff receives has been released or discharged;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(j): endorse on all process and notices the year, month, day, hour, and minute of reception, and, upon payment of fees, issue a certificate to the person delivering process or notice showing the names of the parties, title of paper, and the time of receipt;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(k): serve all process and notices as prescribed by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(l): if the sheriff makes service of process or notice, certify on the process or notices the manner, time, and place of service, or, if the sheriff fails to make service, certify the reason upon the process or notice, and return them without delay;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(m): extinguish fires occurring in the undergrowth, trees, or wooded areas on the public land within his county;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(n): 17-53-311 perform as required by any contracts between the county and private contractors for management, maintenance, operation, and construction of county jails entered into under the authority of Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(o): for the sheriff of a county of the second through sixth class that enters into an interlocal agreement for law enforcement service under Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act, provide law enforcement service as provided in the interlocal agreement;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(p): manage and direct search and rescue services in his county, including emergency medical responders and other related incident response activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(q): 53-10-404 obtain saliva DNA specimens as required under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(r): on or before January 1, 2003, adopt a written policy that prohibits the stopping, detention, or search of any person when the action is solely motivated by considerations of race, color, ethnicity, age, or gender;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(s): 80-1-102 as applicable, select a representative of law enforcement to serve as a member of a child protection team, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(t): 53-22-103 appoint a county security chief in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(1)(u): perform any other duties that are required by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(2)(a): Violation of Subsection (1)(j) is a class C misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(2)(b): Violation of any other subsection under Subsection (1) is a class A misdemeanor.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(3): 17-30-3; 17-30a-102; 17-30-3; 11-13-202; 11-13-202; 11-13-103
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(3)(a): 17-30-3; 17-30a-102; 17-30-3 As used in this Subsection (3):
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(3)(a)(i): 17-30-3; 17-30a-102 "Police interlocal entity" means the same as that term is defined in Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(3)(b)(i): serves as the chief executive officer of each police special district and police interlocal entity within the county with respect to the provision of law enforcement service within the boundary of the police special district or police interlocal entity, respectively; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(3)(b)(ii): is subject to the direction of the police special district board of trustees or police interlocal entity governing body, as the case may be, as and to the extent provided by agreement between the police special district or police interlocal entity, respectively, and the sheriff.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(3)(c)(i): does not serve as the chief executive officer of any interlocal entity created under that interlocal agreement, unless the agreement provides for the sheriff to serve as the chief executive officer; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-22-2(3)(c)(ii): shall provide law enforcement service under that interlocal agreement as provided in the agreement.
