Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1 Process for subdivision review and approval.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(1)(a): As used in this section, an "administrative land use authority" means an individual, board, or commission, appointed or employed by a county, including county staff or a county planning commission.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(1)(b): "Administrative land use authority" does not include a county legislative body or a member of a county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(2)(a): This section applies to land use decisions arising from subdivision applications for single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, or townhomes.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(2)(b): This section does not apply to land use regulations adopted, approved, or agreed upon by a legislative body exercising land use authority in the review of land use applications for zoning or other land use regulation approvals.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(3): 17-27a-605; 17-27a-605 A county ordinance governing the subdivision of land shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(3)(a): comply with this section and establish a standard method and form of application for preliminary subdivision applications and final subdivision applications; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(3)(b): 17-27a-605; 17-27a-605
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(3)(b)(i): designate a single administrative land use authority for the review of preliminary applications to subdivide land; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(3)(b)(ii): 17-27a-605; 17-27a-605 if the county has adopted an ordinance that establishes a separate procedure for the review and approval of subdivisions under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(4)(a): If an applicant requests a pre-application meeting, the county shall, within 15 business days after the request, schedule the meeting to review the concept plan and give initial feedback.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(4)(b): At the pre-application meeting, the county staff shall provide or have available on the county website the following:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(4)(b)(i): copies of applicable land use regulations;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(4)(b)(ii): a complete list of standards required for the project;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(4)(b)(iii): preliminary and final application checklists; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(4)(b)(iv): feedback on the concept plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(5): A preliminary subdivision application shall comply with all applicable county ordinances and requirements of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(6): An administrative land use authority may complete a preliminary subdivision application review in a public meeting or at a county staff level.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(7): With respect to a preliminary application to subdivide land, an administrative land use authority may:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(7)(a): receive public comment; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(7)(b): hold no more than one public hearing.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(8): If a preliminary subdivision application complies with the applicable county ordinances and the requirements of this section, the administrative land use authority shall approve the preliminary subdivision application.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(9): A county shall review and approve or deny a final subdivision plat application in accordance with the provisions of this section and county ordinances, which:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(9)(a): may permit concurrent processing of the final subdivision plat application with the preliminary subdivision plat application; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(9)(b): may not require planning commission or county legislative body approval.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.1(10): (9)(a) If a final subdivision application complies with the requirements of this section, the applicable county ordinances, and the preliminary subdivision approval granted under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2 Review of subdivision land use applications and subdivision improvement plans.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(a): "Review cycle" means the occurrence of:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(a)(i): the applicant's submittal of a complete subdivision land use application;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(a)(ii): the county's review of that subdivision land use application;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(a)(iii): the county's response to that subdivision land use application, in accordance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(a)(iv): the applicant's reply to the county's response that addresses each of the county's required modifications or requests for additional information.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(b): "Subdivision improvement plans" means the civil engineering plans associated with required infrastructure and county-controlled utilities required for a subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(c): "Subdivision ordinance review" means review by a county to verify that a subdivision land use application meets the criteria of the county's subdivision ordinances.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(d): "Subdivision plan review" means a review of the applicant's subdivision improvement plans and other aspects of the subdivision land use application to verify that the application complies with county ordinances and applicable standards and specifications.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(2): The review cycle restrictions and requirements of this section do not apply to the review of subdivision applications affecting property within identified geological hazard areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(3)(a): No later than 15 business days after the day on which an applicant submits a complete preliminary subdivision land use application for a residential subdivision for single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, or townhomes, the county shall complete the initial review of the application, including subdivision improvement plans.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(3)(b): A county shall maintain and publish a list of the items comprising the complete preliminary subdivision land use application, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(3)(b)(i): the application;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(3)(b)(ii): the owner's affidavit;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(3)(b)(iii): an electronic copy of all plans in PDF format;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(3)(b)(iv): the preliminary subdivision plat drawings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(3)(b)(v): a breakdown of fees due upon approval of the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(4)(a): A county shall publish a list of the items that comprise a complete final subdivision land use application.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(4)(b): No later than 20 business days after the day on which an applicant submits a plat, the county shall complete a review of the applicant's final subdivision land use application for single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, or townhomes, including all subdivision plan reviews.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5): (5)(a)(i); (ii); (5)(d)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(a): In reviewing a subdivision land use application, a county may require:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(a)(i): additional information relating to an applicant's plans to ensure compliance with county ordinances and approved standards and specifications for construction of public improvements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(a)(ii): modifications to plans that do not meet current ordinances, applicable standards, or specifications or do not contain complete information.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(b): (5)(a)(i); (ii) A county's request for additional information or modifications to plans under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(c): A county may not require more than four review cycles.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(d): (5)(d)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(d)(i): (5)(d)(ii) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(d)(ii): A modification or correction necessary to protect public health and safety or to enforce state or federal law may not be waived.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(d)(iii): If an applicant makes a material change to a plan set, the county has the discretion to restart the review process at the first review of the final application, but only with respect to the portion of the plan set that the material change substantively effects.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(e): If an applicant does not submit a revised plan within 20 business days after the county requires a modification or correction, the county shall have an additional 20 business days to respond to the plans.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(6): After the applicant has responded to the final review cycle, and the applicant has complied with each modification requested in the county's previous review cycle, the county may not require additional revisions if the applicant has not materially changed the plan, other than changes that were in response to requested modifications or corrections.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(7)(a): In addition to revised plans, an applicant shall provide a written explanation in response to the county's review comments, identifying and explaining the applicant's revisions and reasons for declining to make revisions, if any.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(7)(b): The applicant's written explanation shall be comprehensive and specific, including citations to applicable standards and ordinances for the design and an index of requested revisions or additions for each required correction.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(7)(c): If an applicant fails to address a review comment in the response, the review cycle is not complete and the subsequent review cycle may not begin until all comments are addressed.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8): 17-27a-507(5)(d)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(a): 17-27a-507(5)(d) If, on the fourth or final review, a county fails to respond within 20 business days, the county shall, upon request of the property owner, and within 10 business days after the day on which the request is received:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(a)(i): 17-27a-507(5)(d) for a dispute arising from the subdivision improvement plans, assemble an appeal panel in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(a)(ii): for a dispute arising from the subdivision ordinance review, advise the applicant, in writing, of the deficiency in the application and of the right to appeal the determination to a designated appeal authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2 Review of subdivision  applications and subdivision improvement plans.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(a): "Review cycle" means the occurrence of:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(a)(i): the applicant's submittal of a complete subdivision application;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(a)(ii): the county's review of that subdivision application;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(a)(iii): the county's response to that subdivision application, in accordance with this section; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(a)(iv): the applicant's reply to the county's response that addresses each of the county's required modifications or requests for additional information.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(b): "Subdivision application" means a land use application for the subdivision of land located within the unincorporated area of a county.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(c): "Subdivision improvement plans" means the civil engineering plans associated with required infrastructure improvements and county-controlled utilities required for a subdivision.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(d): "Subdivision ordinance review" means review by a county to verify that a subdivision application meets the criteria of the county's ordinances.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(1)(e): "Subdivision plan review" means a review of the applicant's subdivision improvement plans and other aspects of the subdivision application to verify that the application complies with county ordinances and applicableinstallation standards and inspection specifications for infrastructure improvements.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(2): The review cycle restrictions and requirements of this section do not apply to the review of subdivision applications affecting property within identified geological hazard areas.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(3)(a): A county may require a subdivision improvement plan to be submitted with a subdivision application.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(3)(b): A county may not require a subdivision improvement plan to be submitted with both a preliminary subdivision application and a final subdivision application.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(4)(a): The review cycle requirements of this section apply:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(4)(a)(i): to the review of a preliminary subdivision application, if the county requires a subdivision improvement plan to be submitted with a preliminary subdivision application; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(4)(a)(ii): to the review of a final subdivision application, if the county requires a subdivision improvement plan to be submitted with a final subdivision application.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(4)(b): A county may not, outside the review cycle, engage in a substantive review of required infrastructure improvements or a county controlled utility.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(a): A county shall complete the initial review of a complete subdivision application submitted for ordinance review for a residential subdivision for single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, or town homes:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(a)(i): no later than 15 business days after the complete subdivision application is submitted, if the county has a population over 5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(a)(ii): no later than 30 business days after the complete subdivision application is submitted, if the county has a population of 5,000 or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(b): A county shall maintain and publish a list of the items comprising the complete subdivision application, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(b)(i): the application;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(b)(ii): the owner's affidavit;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(b)(iii): an electronic copy of all plans in PDF format;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(b)(iv): the preliminary subdivision plat drawings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(5)(b)(v): a breakdown of fees due upon approval of the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(6): A county shall publish a list of the items that comprise a complete subdivision land use application.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(7): A county shall complete a subdivision plan review of a subdivision improvement plan that is submitted with a complete subdivision application for a residential subdivision for single-family dwellings, two-family dwellings, or town homes:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(7)(a): within 20 business days after the complete subdivision application is submitted, if the county has a population over 5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(7)(b): within 40 business days after the complete subdivision application is submitted, if the county has a population of 5,000 or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(a): In reviewing a subdivision application, a county may require:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(a)(i): additional information relating to an applicant's plans to ensure compliance with county ordinances and approved standards and specifications for construction of public improvements; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(a)(ii): modifications to plans that do not meet current ordinances, applicable standards, or specifications or do not contain complete information.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(b): A county's request for additional information or modifications to plans under Subsection (8)(a)(i) or (ii) shall be specific and include citations to ordinances, standards, or specifications that require the modifications to subdivision improvement plans, and shall be logged in an index of requested modifications or additions.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(c): A county may not require more than four review cycles for a subdivision improvement plan review.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(d)(i): Subject to Subsection (8)(d)(ii), unless the change or correction is necessitated by the applicant's adjustment to a subdivision improvement plan or an update to a phasing plan that adjusts the infrastructure needed for the specific development, a change or correction not addressed or referenced in a county's subdivision improvement plan review is waived.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(d)(ii): A modification or correction necessary to protect public health and safety or to enforce state or federal law may not be waived.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(d)(iii): If an applicant makes a material change to a subdivision improvement plan, the county has the discretion to restart the review process at the first review of the subdivision improvement plan review, but only with respect to the portion of the subdivision improvement plan that the material change substantively affects.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(e): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(e)(i): This Subsection (8) applies if an applicant does not submit a revised subdivision improvement plan within:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(e)(i)(A): 20 business days after the county requires a modification or correction, if the county has a population over 5,000; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(e)(i)(B): 40 business days after the county requires a modification or correction, if the county has a population of 5,000 or less.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(8)(e)(ii): If an applicant does not submit a revised subdivision improvement plan within the time specified in Subsection (8)(e)(i), a county has an additional 20 business days after the time specified in Subsection (7) to respond to a revised subdivision improvement plan.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(9): After the applicant has responded to the final review cycle, and the applicant has complied with each modification requested in the county's previous review cycle, the county may not require additional revisions if the applicant has not materially changed the plan, other than changes that were in response to requested modifications or corrections.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(10): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(10)(a): In addition to revised plans, an applicant shall provide a written explanation in response to the county's review comments, identifying and explaining the applicant's revisions and reasons for declining to make revisions, if any.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(10)(b): The applicant's written explanation shall be comprehensive and specific, including citations to applicable standards and ordinances for the design and an index of requested revisions or additions for each required correction.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(10)(c): If an applicant fails to address a review comment in the response, the review cycle is not complete and the subsequent review cycle may not begin until all comments are addressed.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(11): 17-27a-507
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(11)(a): 17-27a-507 If, on the fourth or final review, a county fails to respond within 20 business days, the county shall, upon request of the property owner, and within 10 business days after the day on which the request is received:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(11)(a)(i): 17-27a-507 for a dispute arising from the subdivision improvement plans, assemble an appeal panel in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.2(11)(a)(ii): for a dispute arising from the subdivision ordinance review, advise the applicant, in writing, of the deficiency in the application and of the right to appeal the determination to a designated appeal authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5 Subdivision plat recording or development activity before required infrastructure is completed -- Improvement completion assurance -- Improvement warranty.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(1): As used in this section, "public landscaping improvement" means landscaping that an applicant is required to install to comply with published installation and inspection specifications for public improvements that:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(1)(a): will be dedicated to and maintained by the county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(1)(b): are associated with and proximate to trail improvements that connect to planned or existing public infrastructure.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(2): A land use authority shall establish objective inspection standards for acceptance of a required public landscaping improvement or infrastructure improvement.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3): 17-27a-802; 17-27a-103
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(a): Before an applicant conducts any development activity or records a plat, the applicant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(a)(i): complete any required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(a)(ii): post an improvement completion assurance for any required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(b): If an applicant elects to post an improvement completion assurance, the applicant shall provide completion assurance for:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(b)(i): completion of 100% of the required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(b)(ii): if the county has inspected and accepted a portion of the public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements, 100% of the incomplete or unaccepted public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(c): 17-27a-802 A county shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(c)(i): establish a minimum of two acceptable forms of completion assurance;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(c)(ii): if an applicant elects to post an improvement completion assurance, allow the applicant to post an assurance that meets the conditions of this title, and any local ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(c)(iii): establish a system for the partial release of an improvement completion assurance as portions of required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements are completed and accepted in accordance with local ordinance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(c)(iv): 17-27a-802 issue or deny a building permit in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(d): 17-27a-103 A county may not require an applicant to post an improvement completion assurance for:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(d)(i): public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements that the county has previously inspected and accepted;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(d)(ii): infrastructure improvements that are private and not essential or required to meet the building code, fire code, flood or storm water management provisions, street and access requirements, or other essential necessary public safety improvements adopted in a land use regulation; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(d)(iii): in a county where ordinances require all infrastructure improvements within the area to be private, infrastructure improvements within a development that the county requires to be private;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(d)(iv): 17-27a-103 landscaping improvements that are not public landscaping improvements, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(4): (4)(c); (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(4)(a): (4)(c) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(4)(b): (4)(a) Any agreement regarding a completion assurance bond under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(4)(c): A county may not require a completion assurance bond for the landscaping of residential lots or the equivalent open space surrounding single-family attached homes, whether platted as lots or common area.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(5): (3); (4) The sum of the improvement completion assurance required under Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(5)(a): 100% of the estimated cost of the public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements, as evidenced by an engineer's estimate or licensed contractor's bid; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(5)(b): 10% of the amount of the bond to cover administrative costs incurred by the county to complete the improvements, if necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(6): At any time before a county accepts a public landscaping improvement or infrastructure improvement, and for the duration of each improvement warranty period, the land use authority may require the applicant to:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(6)(a): execute an improvement warranty for the improvement warranty period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(6)(b): post a cash deposit, surety bond, letter of credit, or other similar security, as required by the county, in the amount of up to 10% of the lesser of the:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(6)(b)(i): county engineer's original estimated cost of completion; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(6)(b)(ii): applicant's reasonable proven cost of completion.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(7): (3)(c)(ii) When a county accepts an improvement completion assurance for public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements for a development in accordance with Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(8): The provisions of this section do not supersede the terms of a valid development agreement, an adopted phasing plan, or the state construction code.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5 Subdivision plat recording or development activity before required infrastructure is completed -- Improvement completion assurance -- Improvement warranty.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(1): As used in this section, "public landscaping improvement" means landscaping that an applicant is required to install to comply with published installation and inspection specifications for public improvements that:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(1)(a): will be dedicated to and maintained by the county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(1)(b): are associated with and proximate to trail improvements that connect to planned or existing public infrastructure.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(2): A land use authority shall establish objective inspection standards for acceptance of a required public landscaping improvement or infrastructure improvement.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3): 17-27a-802
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(a): Before an applicant conducts any development activity or records a plat, the applicant shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(a)(i): complete any required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(a)(ii): post an improvement completion assurance for any required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(b): If an applicant elects to post an improvement completion assurance, the applicant shall provide completion assurance for:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(b)(i): completion of 100% of the required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(b)(ii): if the county has inspected and accepted a portion of the public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements, 100% of the incomplete or unaccepted public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(c): 17-27a-802 A county shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(c)(i): establish a minimum of two acceptable forms of completion assurance;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(c)(ii): if an applicant elects to post an improvement completion assurance, allow the applicant to post an assurance that meets the conditions of this title, and any local ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(c)(iii): establish a system for the partial release of an improvement completion assurance as portions of required public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements are completed and accepted in accordance with local ordinance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(c)(iv): 17-27a-802 issue or deny a building permit in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(d): A county may not require an applicant to post an improvement completion assurance for:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(d)(i): public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements that the county has previously inspected and accepted;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(d)(ii): infrastructure improvements that are private and not essential or required to meet the building code, fire code, flood or storm water management provisions, street and access requirements, or other essential necessary public safety improvements adopted in a land use regulation;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(d)(iii): in a county where ordinances require all infrastructure improvements within the area to be private, infrastructure improvements within a development that the county requires to be private; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(3)(d)(iv): landscaping improvements that are not public landscaping improvements, unless the landscaping improvements and completion assurance are required under the terms of a development agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(4)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (4)(c), as a condition for increased density or other entitlement benefit not currently available under the existing zone, a county may require a completion assurance bond for landscaped amenities and common area that are dedicated to and maintained by a homeowners association.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(4)(b): Any agreement regarding a completion assurance bond under Subsection (4)(a) between the applicant and the county shall be memorialized in a development agreement.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(4)(c): A county may not require a completion assurance bond for or dictate who installs or is responsible for the cost of the landscaping of residential lots or the equivalent open space surrounding single-family attached homes, whether platted as lots or common area.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(5): The sum of the improvement completion assurance required under Subsections (3) and (4) may not exceed the sum of:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(5)(a): 100% of the estimated cost of the public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements, as evidenced by an engineer's estimate or licensed contractor's bid; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(5)(b): 10% of the amount of the bond to cover administrative costs incurred by the county to complete the improvements, if necessary.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(6): At any time before a county accepts a public landscaping improvement or infrastructure improvement, and for the duration of each improvement warranty period, the land use authority may require the applicant to:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(6)(a): execute an improvement warranty for the improvement warranty period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(6)(b): post a cash deposit, surety bond, letter of credit, or other similar security, as required by the county, in the amount of up to 10% of the lesser of the:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(6)(b)(i): county engineer's original estimated cost of completion; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(6)(b)(ii): applicant's reasonable proven cost of completion.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(7): When a county accepts an improvement completion assurance for public landscaping improvements or infrastructure improvements for a development in accordance with Subsection (3)(c)(ii), the county may not deny an applicant a building permit if the development meets the requirements for the issuance of a building permit under the building code and fire code.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-604.5(8): The provisions of this section do not supersede the terms of a valid development agreement, an adopted phasing plan, or the state construction code.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-605 Exemptions from plat requirement.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-605(1): Notwithstanding any other provision of law, a plat is not required if:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-605(1)(a): a county establishes a process to approve an administrative land use decision for the subdivision of unincorporated land or mountainous planning district land into 10 or fewer lots without a plat; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-605(1)(b): the county provides in writing that:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-605(1)(b)(i): the county has provided notice as required by ordinance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-605(1)(b)(ii): the proposed subdivision:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-605(1)(b)(ii)(A): is not traversed by the mapped lines of a proposed street as shown in the general plan unless the county has approved the location and dedication of any public street, county utility easement, any other easement, or any other land for public purposes as the county's ordinance requires;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-605(1)(b)(ii)(B): has been approved by the culinary water authority and the sanitary sewer authority;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-605(1)(b)(ii)(C): is located in a zoned area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-605(1)(b)(ii)(D): conforms to all applicable land use ordinances or has properly received a variance from the requirements of an otherwise conflicting and applicable land use ordinance.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-607 Dedication by plat of public streets and other public places.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-607(1): A plat that is signed, dedicated, and acknowledged by each owner of record, and approved according to the procedures specified in this part, operates, when recorded, as a dedication of all public streets and other public places, and vests the fee of those parcels of land in the county for the public for the uses named or intended in the plat.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-607(2): The dedication established by this section does not impose liability upon the county for public streets and other public places that are dedicated in this manner but are unimproved unless:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-607(2)(a): adequate financial assurance has been provided in accordance with this chapter; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-607(2)(b): the county has accepted the dedication.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-610 Restrictions for solar and other energy devices.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The land use authority may refuse to approve or renew any plat, subdivision plan, or dedication of any street or other ground, if deed restrictions, covenants, or similar binding agreements running with the land for the lots or parcels covered by the plat or subdivision prohibit or have the effect of prohibiting reasonably sited and designed solar collectors, clotheslines, or other energy devices based on renewable resources from being installed on buildings erected on lots or parcels covered by the plat or subdivision.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-611(1)(b): (1)(a) The description by metes and bounds in an instrument of transfer or other documents used in the process of selling or transferring does not exempt the transaction from being a violation of Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-611(1)(c): (1) Notwithstanding any other provision of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-611(1)(c)(i): does not affect the validity of the instrument or other document; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-611(1)(c)(ii): does not affect whether the property that is the subject of the instrument or other document complies with applicable county ordinances on land use and development.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701 Appeal authority required -- Condition precedent to judicial review -- Appeal authority duties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(1): 17-27a-509
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(1)(a): Each county adopting a land use ordinance shall, by ordinance, establish one or more appeal authorities.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(1)(b): 17-27a-509 An appeal authority shall hear and decide:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(1)(b)(i): requests for variances from the terms of land use ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(1)(b)(ii): appeals from land use decisions applying land use ordinances; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(1)(b)(iii): 17-27a-509 appeals from a fee charged in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(1)(c): An appeal authority may not hear an appeal from the enactment of a land use regulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(2): As a condition precedent to judicial review, each adversely affected party shall timely and specifically challenge a land use authority's land use decision, in accordance with local ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(3): (1)(a) An appeal authority described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(3)(a): shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(3)(a)(i): act in a quasi-judicial manner; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(3)(a)(ii): serve as the final arbiter of issues involving the interpretation or application of land use ordinances; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(3)(b): may not entertain an appeal of a matter in which the appeal authority, or any participating member, had first acted as the land use authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(4): By ordinance, a county may:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(4)(a): designate a separate appeal authority to hear requests for variances than the appeal authority the county designates to hear appeals;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(4)(b): designate one or more separate appeal authorities to hear distinct types of appeals of land use authority decisions;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(4)(c): require an adversely affected party to present to an appeal authority every theory of relief that the adversely affected party can raise in district court;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(4)(d): not require a land use applicant or adversely affected party to pursue duplicate or successive appeals before the same or separate appeal authorities as a condition of an appealing party's duty to exhaust administrative remedies; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(4)(e): provide that specified types of land use decisions may be appealed directly to the district court.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(5): If the county establishes or, prior to the effective date of this chapter, has established a multiperson board, body, or panel to act as an appeal authority, at a minimum the board, body, or panel shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(5)(a): notify each of the members of the board, body, or panel of any meeting or hearing of the board, body, or panel;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(5)(b): provide each of the members of the board, body, or panel with the same information and access to municipal resources as any other member;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(5)(c): convene only if a quorum of the members of the board, body, or panel is present; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-701(5)(d): act only upon the vote of a majority of the convened members of the board, body, or panel.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702 Variances.
-------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(1): Any person or entity desiring a waiver or modification of the requirements of a land use ordinance as applied to a parcel of property that he owns, leases, or in which he holds some other beneficial interest may apply to the applicable appeal authority for a variance from the terms of the ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2): (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(a): The appeal authority may grant a variance only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(a)(i): literal enforcement of the ordinance would cause an unreasonable hardship for the applicant that is not necessary to carry out the general purpose of the land use ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(a)(ii): there are special circumstances attached to the property that do not generally apply to other properties in the same zone;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(a)(iii): granting the variance is essential to the enjoyment of a substantial property right possessed by other property in the same zone;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(a)(iv): the variance will not substantially affect the general plan and will not be contrary to the public interest; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(a)(v): the spirit of the land use ordinance is observed and substantial justice done.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(b): (2)(a); (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(b)(i): (2)(a) In determining whether or not enforcement of the land use ordinance would cause unreasonable hardship under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(b)(i)(A): is located on or associated with the property for which the variance is sought; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(b)(i)(B): comes from circumstances peculiar to the property, not from conditions that are general to the neighborhood.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(b)(ii): (2)(a) In determining whether or not enforcement of the land use ordinance would cause unreasonable hardship under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(c): (2)(a) In determining whether or not there are special circumstances attached to the property under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(c)(i): relate to the hardship complained of; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(2)(c)(ii): deprive the property of privileges granted to other properties in the same zone.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(3): The applicant shall bear the burden of proving that all of the conditions justifying a variance have been met.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(4): Variances run with the land.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(5): The appeal authority may not grant a use variance.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(6): In granting a variance, the appeal authority may impose additional requirements on the applicant that will:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(6)(a): mitigate any harmful affects of the variance; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-702(6)(b): serve the purpose of the standard or requirement that is waived or modified.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-703 Appealing a land use authority's decision -- Panel of experts for appeals of geologic hazard decisions.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-703(1): The land use applicant, a board or officer of the county, or an adversely affected party may, within the time period provided by ordinance, appeal that decision to the appeal authority by alleging that there is error in any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by the land use authority in the administration or interpretation of the land use ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-703(2): (2)(a); (2)(a); (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-703(2)(a): A land use applicant who has appealed a decision of the land use authority administering or interpreting the county's geologic hazard ordinance may request the county to assemble a panel of qualified experts to serve as the appeal authority for purposes of determining the technical aspects of the appeal.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-703(2)(b): (2)(a); (2)(a) If a land use applicant makes a request under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-703(2)(b)(i): one expert designated by the county;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-703(2)(b)(ii): one expert designated by the land use applicant; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-703(2)(b)(iii): one expert chosen jointly by the county's designated expert and the applicant's land use designated expert.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-703(2)(c): (2)(b) A member of the panel assembled by the county under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-703(2)(d): The land use applicant shall pay:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-703(2)(d)(i): 1/2 of the cost of the panel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-703(2)(d)(ii): the county's published appeal fee.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-704 Time to appeal.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-704(1): The county shall enact an ordinance establishing a reasonable time of not less than 10 days to appeal to an appeal authority a written decision issued by a land use authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-704(2): In the absence of an ordinance establishing a reasonable time to appeal, a land use applicant or adversely affected party shall have 10 calendar days to appeal to an appeal authority a written decision issued by a land use authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-705 Burden of proof.
-------------------------------------------------
The appellant has the burden of proving that the land use authority erred.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-706 Due process.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-706(1): Each appeal authority shall conduct each appeal and variance request as described by local ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-706(2): Each appeal authority shall respect the due process rights of each of the participants.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-707 Scope of review of factual matters on appeal -- Appeal authority requirements.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-707(1): A county may, by ordinance, designate the scope of review of factual matters for appeals of land use authority decisions.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-707(2): If the county fails to designate a scope of review of factual matters, the appeal authority shall review the matter de novo, without deference to the land use authority's determination of factual matters.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-707(3): If the scope of review of factual matters is on the record, the appeal authority shall determine whether the record on appeal includes substantial evidence for each essential finding of fact.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-707(4): The appeal authority shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-707(4)(a): determine the correctness of the land use authority's interpretation and application of the plain meaning of the land use regulations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-707(4)(b): interpret and apply a land use regulation to favor a land use application unless the land use regulation plainly restricts the land use application.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-707(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-707(5)(a): An appeal authority's land use decision is a quasi-judicial act.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-707(5)(b): A legislative body may act as an appeal authority unless both the legislative body and the appealing party agree to allow a third party to act as the appeal authority.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-707(6): Only a decision in which a land use authority has applied a land use regulation to a particular land use application, person, or parcel may be appealed to an appeal authority.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-708 Final decision.
------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-708(1): A decision of an appeal authority takes effect on the date when the appeal authority issues a written decision, or as otherwise provided by local ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-708(2): 17-27a-801(2)(a); 17-27a-801(4) A written decision, or other event as provided by ordinance, constitutes a final decision under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-802 Enforcement.
---------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-802(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-802(1)(a): A county or an adversely affected party may, in addition to other remedies provided by law, institute:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-802(1)(a)(i): injunctions, mandamus, abatement, or any other appropriate actions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-802(1)(a)(ii): proceedings to prevent, enjoin, abate, or remove the unlawful building, use, or act.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-802(1)(b): A county need only establish the violation to obtain the injunction.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-802(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-802(2)(a): A county may enforce the county's ordinance by withholding a building permit.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-802(2)(b): It is unlawful to erect, construct, reconstruct, alter, or change the use of any building or other structure within a county without approval of a building permit.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-802(2)(c): The county may not issue a building permit unless the plans of and for the proposed erection, construction, reconstruction, alteration, or use fully conform to all regulations then in effect.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-802(2)(d): A county may not deny an applicant a building permit or certificate of occupancy because the applicant has not completed an infrastructure improvement:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-802(2)(d)(i): that is not essential to meet the requirements for the issuance of a building permit or certificate of occupancy under the building code and fire code; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-802(2)(d)(ii): for which the county has accepted an improvement completion assurance for landscaping or infrastructure improvements for the development.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-803 Penalties -- Notice.
-----------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-803(1): The county may, by ordinance, establish civil penalties for violations of any of the provisions of this chapter or of any ordinances adopted under the authority of this chapter.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-803(2): Violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or of any ordinances adopted under the authority of this chapter is punishable as a class C misdemeanor upon conviction either:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-803(2)(a): as a class C misdemeanor; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-803(2)(b): by imposing the appropriate civil penalty adopted under the authority of this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-803(3): Prior to imposing upon an owner of record a civil penalty established by ordinance under authority of this chapter, a county shall provide:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-803(3)(a): written notice, by mail or hand delivery, of each ordinance violation to the address of the:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-803(3)(a)(i): owner of record on file in the office of the county recorder; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-803(3)(a)(ii): person designated, in writing, by the owner of record as the owner's agent for the purpose of receiving notice of an ordinance violation;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-803(3)(b): the owner of record a reasonable opportunity to cure a noticed violation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-803(3)(c): a schedule of the civil penalties that may be imposed upon the expiration of a time certain.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-901 Mountainous planning district.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-901(1): (1)(a)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-901(1)(a): The legislative body of a county of the first class may adopt an ordinance designating an area located within the county as a mountainous planning district if the legislative body determines that:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-901(1)(a)(i): the area is primarily used for recreational purposes, including canyons, foothills, ski resorts, wilderness areas, lakes and reservoirs, campgrounds, or picnic areas within the Wasatch Range;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-901(1)(a)(ii): the area is used by residents of the county who live inside and outside the limits of a municipality;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-901(1)(a)(iii): the total resident population in the proposed mountainous planning district is equal to or less than 5% of the population of the county;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-901(1)(a)(iv): the area is within the unincorporated area of the county or was within the unincorporated area of the county before May 12, 2015; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-901(1)(a)(v): the area includes land designated as part of a national forest on or before May 9, 2017.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-901(1)(b): (1)(a)(iii) The population figure under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-901(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-901(2)(a): A county may adopt a general plan and adopt a zoning or subdivision ordinance for a property that is located within a mountainous planning district.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-901(2)(b): (2)(a) A county plan or zoning or subdivision ordinance governs a property described in Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1001 Definitions.
----------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1001(1): "Critical infrastructure materials" means sand, gravel, or rock aggregate.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1001(2): "Critical infrastructure materials operations" means the extraction, excavation, processing, or reprocessing of critical infrastructure materials.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1001(3): "Critical infrastructure materials operator" means a natural person, corporation, association, partnership, receiver, trustee, executor, administrator, guardian, fiduciary, agent, or other organization or representative, either public or private, including a successor, assign, affiliate, subsidiary, and related parent company, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1001(3)(a): owns, controls, or manages a critical infrastructure materials operations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1001(3)(b): has produced commercial quantities of critical infrastructure materials from the critical infrastructure materials operations.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1001(4): "Vested critical infrastructure materials operations" means critical infrastructure materials operations operating in accordance with a legal nonconforming use or a permit issued by the county that existed or was conducted or otherwise engaged in before:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1001(4)(a): a political subdivision prohibits, restricts, or otherwise limits the critical infrastructure materials operations; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1001(4)(b): January 1, 2019.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1002 Vested critical infrastructure materials operations -- Conclusive presumption.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1002(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1002(1)(a): Critical infrastructure materials operations operating in accordance with a legal nonconforming use or a permit issued by the county are conclusively presumed to be vested critical infrastructure materials operations if the critical infrastructure materials operations permitted by the county, existed or was conducted or otherwise engaged in before January 1, 2019 and before when a political subdivision prohibits, restricts, or otherwise limits the critical infrastructure materials operations.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1002(1)(b): A person claiming that a vested critical infrastructure materials operations has been established has the burden of proof to show by the preponderance of the evidence that the vested critical infrastructure materials operations has been established.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1002(2): A vested critical infrastructure materials operations:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1002(2)(a): runs with the land; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1002(2)(b): may be changed to another critical infrastructure materials operations conducted within the scope of a legal nonconforming use or the permit for the vested critical infrastructure materials operations without losing its status as a vested critical infrastructure materials operations.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1003 Rights of a critical infrastructure materials operator with a vested critical infrastructure materials operations.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Notwithstanding a political subdivision's prohibition, restriction, or other limitation on a critical infrastructure materials operations adopted after the establishment of the critical infrastructure materials operations, the rights of a critical infrastructure materials operator with vested critical infrastructure materials operations include the right to:Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1003(1): use, operate, construct, reconstruct, restore, maintain, repair, alter, substitute, modernize, upgrade, and replace equipment, processes, facilities, and buildings; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1003(2): discontinue, suspend, terminate, deactivate, or continue and reactivate, temporarily or permanently, all or any part of the critical infrastructure materials operations.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1004 Notice.
-----------------------------------------
For any new subdivision development located in whole or in part within 1,000 feet of the boundary of a vested critical infrastructure materials operations, the owner of the development shall provide notice on any plat filed with the county recorder the following notice:

Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1005 Abandonment of a vested critical infrastructure materials operations.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1005(1): A critical infrastructure materials operator may abandon some or all of a vested critical infrastructure materials operations use only as provided in this section.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1005(2): To abandon some or all of a vested critical infrastructure materials operations, a critical infrastructure materials operator shall record a written declaration of abandonment with the recorder of the county in which the vested critical infrastructure materials operations being abandoned is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1005(3): (2) The written declaration of abandonment under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1101 Title.
----------------------------------------
This part is known as the "Large Concentrated Animal Feeding Operations Act."

Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102 Definitions.
----------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(1): "Animal feeding operation" means a lot or facility where the following conditions are met:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(1)(a): animals have been, are, or will be stabled or confined and fed or maintained for a total of 45 days or more in any 12-month period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(1)(b): crops, vegetation, forage growth, or post-harvest residues are not sustained in the normal growing season over any portion of the lot or facility.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(2)(a): "Commercial enterprise" means a building:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(2)(a)(i): used as a part of a business that manufactures goods, delivers services, or sells goods or services;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(2)(a)(ii): customarily and regularly used by the general public during the entire calendar year; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(2)(a)(iii): connected to electric or water systems.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(2)(b): "Commercial enterprise" does not include an agriculture operation.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(3): 17-27a-1103 "County large concentrated animal feeding operation land use ordinance" means an ordinance adopted in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(4): 53B-3-102 "Education institution" means a building in which any part is used:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(4)(a): for more than three hours each weekday during a school year as a public or private:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(4)(a)(i): elementary school;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(4)(a)(ii): secondary school; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(4)(a)(iii): kindergarten;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(4)(b): 53B-3-102 a state institution of higher education as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(4)(c): a private institution of higher education in the state accredited by a regional or national accrediting agency recognized by the United States Department of Education.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(5): 26B-2-201 "Health care facility" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6): "Large concentrated animal feeding operation" means an animal feeding operation that stables or confines as many as or more than the numbers of animals specified in any of the following categories:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6)(a): 700 mature dairy cows, whether milked or dry;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6)(b): 1,000 veal calves;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6)(c): 1,000 cattle other than mature dairy cows or veal calves, with "cattle" including heifers, steers, bulls, and cow calf pairs;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6)(d): 2,500 swine each weighing 55 pounds or more;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6)(e): 10,000 swine each weighing less than 55 pounds;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6)(f): 500 horses;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6)(g): 10,000 sheep or lambs;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6)(h): 55,000 turkeys;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6)(i): 30,000 laying hens or broilers, if the animal feeding operation uses a liquid manure handling system;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6)(j): 125,000 chickens, other than laying hens, if the animal feeding operation uses other than a liquid manure handling system;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6)(k): 82,000 laying hens, if the animal feeding operation uses other than a liquid manure handling system;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6)(l): 30,000 ducks, if the animal feeding operation uses other than a liquid manure handling system; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(6)(m): 5,000 ducks, if the animal feeding operation uses a liquid manure handling system.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(7): "Manure" includes manure, bedding, compost, a raw material, or other material commingled with manure or set aside for disposal.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(8): "Public area" means land that:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(8)(a): is owned by the federal government, the state, or a political subdivision with facilities that attract the public to congregate and remain in the area for significant periods of time;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(8)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(8)(b)(i): is part of a public park, preserve, or recreation area that is owned or managed by the federal government, the state, a political subdivision, or a nongovernmental entity; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(8)(b)(ii): has a cultural, archaeological, scientific, or historic significance or contains a rare or valuable ecological system, including a site recognized as a National Historic Landmark or Site; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(8)(c): is a cemetery.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-27a-1102(9): "Religious institution" means a building and grounds used at least monthly for religious services or ceremonies.
