Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(16)(b)(i): any sampling, staking, surveying, exploration, or development activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(16)(b)(ii): any drilling, blasting, excavating, or tunneling;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(16)(b)(iii): the removal, transport, treatment, deposition, and reclamation of overburden, development rock, tailings, and other waste material;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(16)(b)(iv): any removal, transportation, extraction, beneficiation, or processing of ore;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(16)(b)(v): any smelting, refining, autoclaving, or other primary or secondary processing operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(16)(b)(vi): the recovery of any mineral left in residue from a previous extraction or processing operation;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(16)(b)(vii): a mining activity that is identified in a work plan or permitting document;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(16)(b)(viii): the use, operation, maintenance, repair, replacement, or alteration of a building, structure, facility, equipment, machine, tool, or other material or property that results from or is used in a surface or subsurface mining operation or activity;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(16)(b)(ix): any accessory, incidental, or ancillary activity or use, both active and passive, including a utility, private way or road, pipeline, land excavation, working, embankment, pond, gravel excavation, mining waste, conveyor, power line, trackage, storage, reserve, passive use area, buffer zone, and power production facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(16)(b)(x): the construction of a storage, factory, processing, or maintenance facility; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(16)(b)(xi): 40-8-4 an activity described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(17): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(17)(a): "Municipal" means of or relating to a city or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(17)(b): "Municipality" means a city or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(18): "New land" means surface or subsurface land or mineral estate that a mine operator gains ownership or control of, whether that land or mineral estate is included in the mine operator's large mine permit.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(19): 40-8-4 "Off-site" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(20): 40-8-4 "On-site" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(21): "Planning commission" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(21)(a): a countywide planning commission if the land proposed to be included in the agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area is within the unincorporated part of the county and not within a planning advisory area;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(21)(b): a planning advisory area planning commission if the land proposed to be included in the agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area is within a planning advisory area; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(21)(c): a planning commission of a city or town if the land proposed to be included in the agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area is within a city or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(22): "Political subdivision" means a county, city, town, school district, special district, or special service district.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(23): "Proposal sponsors" means the owners of land in agricultural production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials operations who are sponsoring the proposal for creating an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(24): "State agency" means each department, commission, board, council, agency, institution, officer, corporation, fund, division, office, committee, authority, laboratory, library, unit, bureau, panel, or other administrative unit of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(25): "Unincorporated" means not within a city or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(26): "Vested mining use" means a mining use:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(26)(a): by a mine operator; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-101(26)(b): that existed or was conducted or otherwise engaged in before a political subdivision prohibits, restricts, or otherwise limits a mining use.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102 Study of critical infrastructure materials operations and related mining.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(1)(a): "Association of governments" means an association of political subdivisions established pursuant to an interlocal agreement under Title 11, Chapter 13, Interlocal Cooperation Act.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(1)(b): "Metropolitan planning organization" means an organization established under 23 U.S.C. Sec. 134.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(1)(c): "Related mining" means a mining use related to the critical infrastructure materials operations industry.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(1)(d): "Relevant area" means the area included within the boundaries of:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(1)(d)(i): a county of the first, second, or third class;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(1)(d)(ii): a metropolitan planning organization; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(1)(d)(iii): an association of governments that has as a member a county of the first, second, or third class.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2): The division shall conduct a study of critical infrastructure materials operations and related mining that includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(a): an inventory of critical infrastructure materials operations and related mining within the relevant area as of May 1, 2024, to include:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(a)(i): both the number and location of critical infrastructure materials operations;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(a)(ii): levels of production; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(a)(iii): the extent to which the critical infrastructure materials meet standards used by the Department of Transportation;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(b): an inventory of new critical infrastructure materials operations and related mining that may be created by either the establishment of critical infrastructure materials operations or related mining on or after May 1, 2024, or the expansion of existing critical infrastructure materials operations or related mining on or after May 1, 2024, taking into consideration:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(b)(i): zoning; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(b)(ii): supply in the market;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(c): an assessment of projected future demand for critical infrastructure materials within the relevant area, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(c)(i): the effects of residential and commercial development; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(c)(ii): known planned projects, such as transportation projects;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(d): an analysis of the financial costs related to transporting and distributing critical infrastructure materials to and from the relevant area;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(e): an analysis of the impacts of critical infrastructure materials operations and related mining on local infrastructure within the relevant area and possible mitigation of those impacts;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(f): an analysis of the regulatory requirements faced by critical infrastructure materials operations;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(g): the study of whether critical infrastructure materials operations should be licensed, permitted, or otherwise authorized or regulated by the division, another state agency, or local government; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(2)(h): any other issue the division finds relevant to the study of critical infrastructure materials operations and related mining.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(3): In conducting the study, the division shall work cooperatively with:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(3)(a): the Utah League of Cities and Towns;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(3)(b): the Utah Association of Counties;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(3)(c): the Department of Transportation;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(3)(d): the critical infrastructure materials industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(3)(e): the related mining industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(3)(f): the real estate development industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(3)(g): the home builders industry;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(3)(h): a local metropolitan planning organization;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(3)(i): at least two representatives from counties of the first, second, or third class; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(3)(j): at least two representatives from municipalities located within a county of the first, second, or third class.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(4): The division shall complete the initial findings of the study required by this section by no later than November 1, 2024, and report the division's initial findings to the Natural Resources, Agriculture, and Environment Interim Committee by no later than the November 2024 interim meeting of that committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(5): The division shall complete the study required by this section and report the division's findings to the Legislature by no later than the first day of the 2025 legislative annual general session.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-102(6): Notwithstanding other provisions of this section, the division may not include in the division's study any critical infrastructure materials resources within the relevant area if those critical infrastructure materials resources are only extracted for use within an existing mining operation and not offered for sale to the public.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201 Protection area advisory board.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(1): (1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(1)(a): (1)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(1)(a)(i): A county legislative body shall appoint no more than five members from the county's conservation district board of supervisors to serve as the agriculture protection area advisory board.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(1)(a)(ii): A county legislative body shall appoint an industrial protection area advisory board.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(1)(a)(iii): (1)(b) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(1)(a)(iii)(A): the executive director of the Department of Transportation, or the executive director's designee;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(1)(a)(iii)(B): a local government elected official appointed by the county legislative body;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(1)(a)(iii)(C): a representative of a local highway authority appointed by the county legislative body;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(1)(a)(iii)(D): a representative of the critical infrastructure materials industry appointed by the county legislative body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(1)(a)(iii)(E): a representative of the construction industry appointed by the county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(1)(b): A county legislative body may appoint an advisory board before or after a proposal to create an agriculture protection area or industrial protection area is filed. A county legislative body shall appoint a critical infrastructure materials protection area advisory board only after a proposal to create a critical infrastructure materials protection area is filed.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(2): A member of an advisory board shall serve without salary, but a county legislative body may reimburse members for expenses incurred in the performance of their duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(3): An advisory board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(3)(a): evaluate proposals for the establishment of the relevant protection areas and make recommendations to the applicable legislative body about whether the proposal should be accepted;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(3)(b): provide expert advice to the planning commission and to the applicable legislative body about:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(3)(b)(i): the desirability of the proposal;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(3)(b)(ii): the nature of agricultural production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials operations, as the case may be, within the proposed area;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(3)(b)(iii): the relation of agricultural production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials operations, as the case may be, in the area to the county as a whole; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(3)(b)(iv): which agriculture production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials operations, should be allowed within the relevant protection area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-201(3)(c): perform the other duties required by this chapter.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301 Proposal for creation of a protection area.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(1)(a): A proposal to create an agriculture protection area, an industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area may be filed with:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(1)(a)(i): the legislative body of the county in which the area is located, if the area is within the unincorporated part of a county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(1)(a)(ii): the legislative body of the city or town in which the area is located, if the area is within a city or town.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(1)(b): A proposal to create a critical infrastructure protection area can only be initiated by the legislative body of the municipality or county. Creation of a critical infrastructure materials protection area is a legislative act.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(1)(c)(i): To be accepted for processing by the applicable legislative body, a proposal under Subsection (1)(a) shall be signed by a majority in number of all owners of real property and the owners of a majority of the land area in agricultural production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials operations within the proposed relevant protection area.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(1)(c)(ii): For purposes of Subsection (1)(c)(i), the owners of real property shall be determined by the records of the county recorder.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(2): The proposal shall identify:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(2)(a): the boundaries of the land proposed to become part of the relevant protection area;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(2)(b): any limits on the types of agriculture production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials operations to be allowed within the relevant protection area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(2)(c): for each parcel of land:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(2)(c)(i): the names of the owners of record of the land proposed to be included within the relevant protection area;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(2)(c)(ii): the tax parcel number or account number identifying each parcel; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(2)(c)(iii): the number of acres of each parcel.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(3): An agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area may include within its boundaries land used for a roadway, dwelling site, park, or other nonagricultural use, in the case of an industrial protection area, nonindustrial use, or in the case of a critical infrastructure materials protection area, use unrelated to critical infrastructure materials operations, if that land constitutes a minority of the total acreage within the relevant protection area.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(4): 78B-4-512 An agricultural protection area may include within the boundaries of the agricultural protection area an agritourism activity, as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(5): A county or municipal legislative body may establish:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(5)(a): the manner and form for submission of proposals; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(5)(b): reasonable fees for accepting and processing the proposal.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-301(6): A county and municipal legislative body shall establish the minimum number of continuous acres that shall be included in an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-302(3)(a): A person wishing to modify the proposal for the creation of the agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area shall, within 15 days after the date of the notice, file a written request for modification of the proposal, which identifies specifically the land that should be added to or removed from the proposal.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-302(3)(b): A person wishing to object to the proposal for the creation of the agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area shall, within 15 days after the date of the notice, file a written objection to the creation of the relevant protection area.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-305 Criteria to be applied in evaluating a proposal for the creation of a protection area.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In evaluating a proposal and in determining whether or not to create or recommend the creation of an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area, the advisory committee, planning commission, and applicable legislative body shall apply the following criteria:Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-305(1): whether or not the land is currently being used for agriculture production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials operations, as the case may be;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-305(2): whether or not the land is zoned for agriculture use, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials operations, as the case may be;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-305(3): whether or not the land is viable for agriculture production, industrial use, or critical infrastructure materials operations, as the case may be;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-305(4): the extent and nature of existing or proposed farm improvements, the extent and nature of existing or proposed improvements to or expansion of the industrial use, or the extent and nature of existing or proposed improvements to or expansion of critical infrastructure materials operations, as the case may be; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-305(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-305(5)(a): in the case of an agriculture protection area, anticipated trends in agricultural and technological conditions;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-305(5)(b): in the case of an industrial protection area, anticipated trends in technological conditions applicable to the industrial use of the land in question; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-305(5)(c): in the case of a critical infrastructure materials protection area, anticipated trends in technological conditions applicable to the critical infrastructure materials operations of the land in question.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306 Adding land to or removing land from a protection area -- Removing land from a mining protection area.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(1)(a): Any owner may add land to an existing agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, critical infrastructure materials protection area, as the case may be, by:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(1)(a)(i): filing a proposal with:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(1)(a)(i)(A): the county legislative body, if the relevant protection area and the land to be added are within the unincorporated part of the county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(1)(a)(i)(B): the municipal legislative body, if the relevant protection area and the land to be added are within a city or town; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(1)(a)(ii): obtaining the approval of the applicable legislative body for the addition of the land to the relevant protection area.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(1)(b): The applicable legislative body shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(1)(b)(i): comply with the provisions for creating an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, critical infrastructure materials protection area, as the case may be, in determining whether to accept the proposal; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(1)(b)(ii): for purposes of a critical infrastructure materials protection area, request a copy of the applicable Division of Air Quality approval order.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(1)(c): The applicable legislative body may deny the expansion if it is contrary to the Division of Air Quality's approval order.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(2): 17-41-301; (2)(b)(iii); (2)(b)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(2)(a): An owner of land within an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area may remove any or all of the land from the relevant protection area, by filing a petition for removal with the applicable legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(2)(b): 17-41-301; (2)(b)(iii); (2)(b)(iii)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-306(2)(b)(i): 17-41-301 The applicable legislative body:

Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-307 Review of protection areas.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-307(1): In the 20th calendar year after its creation under this part, an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area, as the case may be, shall be reviewed, under the provisions of this section, by:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-307(1)(a): the county legislative body, if the relevant protection area is within the unincorporated part of the county; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-307(1)(b): the municipal legislative body, if the relevant protection area is within the municipality.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-307(2): 17-41-302
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-307(2)(a): 17-41-302 In the 20th year, the applicable legislative body may:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-307(2)(a)(i): request the planning commission and advisory board to submit recommendations about whether the agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area, as the case may be, should be continued, modified, or terminated;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-307(2)(a)(ii): at least 120 days before the end of the calendar year, hold a public hearing to discuss whether the relevant protection area, should be continued, modified, or terminated;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-307(2)(a)(iii): 17-41-302 give notice of the hearing using the same procedures required by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-307(2)(a)(iv): after the public hearing, continue, modify, or terminate the relevant protection area.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-307(2)(b): If the applicable legislative body modifies or terminates the agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area, the applicable legislative body shall file an executed document containing the legal description of the relevant protection area, with the county recorder of deeds.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-307(3): If the applicable legislative body fails affirmatively to continue, modify, or terminate the agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area, as the case may be, in the 20th calendar year, the relevant protection area is considered to be reauthorized for another 20 years.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-402 Limitations on local regulations.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-402(1): A political subdivision within which an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area is created or with a mining protection area within its boundary shall encourage the continuity, development, and viability of agriculture use, industrial use, critical infrastructure materials operations, or mining use, within the relevant protection area by not enacting a local law, ordinance, or regulation that, unless the law, ordinance, or regulation bears a direct relationship to public health or safety, would unreasonably restrict:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-402(1)(a): in the case of an agriculture protection area, a farm structure or farm practice;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-402(1)(b): in the case of an industrial protection area, an industrial use of the land within the area;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-402(1)(c): in the case of a critical infrastructure materials protection area, critical infrastructure materials operations; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-402(1)(d): in the case of a mining protection area, a mining use within the protection area.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-402(2): A political subdivision may not change the zoning designation of or a zoning regulation affecting land within an agriculture protection area unless the political subdivision receives written approval for the change from all the landowners within the agriculture protection area affected by the change.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-402(3): 19-4-113 Except as provided by Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-402(4): A political subdivision may not change the zoning designation of or a zoning regulation affecting land within a critical infrastructure materials protection area unless the political subdivision receives written approval for the change from each critical infrastructure materials operator within the relevant area.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-402(5): A political subdivision may not change the zoning designation of or a zoning regulation affecting land within a mining protection area unless the political subdivision receives written approval for the change from each mine operator within the area.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-402(6): 10-9a-901; 17-27a-1001; 10-9a-509(1)(a)(ii); 17-27a-508(1)(a)(ii) A county, city, or town may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-402(6)(a): 10-9a-901; 17-27a-1001 adopt, enact, or amend an existing land use regulation, ordinance, or regulation that would prohibit, restrict, regulate, or otherwise limit critical infrastructure materials operations, including vested critical infrastructure materials operations as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-402(6)(b): 10-9a-509(1)(a)(ii); 17-27a-508(1)(a)(ii) initiate proceedings to amend the county's, city's, or town's land use ordinances as described in Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403 Nuisances.
------------------------------------------
This property is located in the vicinity of an established agriculture protection area in which normal agricultural uses and activities have been afforded the highest priority use status.  It can be anticipated that such agricultural uses and activities may now or in the future be conducted on property included in the agriculture protection area.  The use and enjoyment of this property is expressly conditioned on acceptance of any annoyance or inconvenience which may result from such normal agricultural uses and activities."Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(1): A political subdivision shall ensure that any of the political subdivision's laws or ordinances that define or prohibit a public nuisance exclude from the definition or prohibition:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(1)(a): for an agriculture protection area, any agricultural activity or operation within an agriculture protection area conducted using sound agricultural practices unless that activity or operation bears a direct relationship to public health or safety;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(1)(b): for an industrial protection area, any industrial use of the land within the industrial protection area that is consistent with sound practices applicable to the industrial use, unless that use bears a direct relationship to public health or safety; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(1)(c): for a critical infrastructure materials protection area, any critical infrastructure materials operations on the land within the critical infrastructure materials protection area that is consistent with sound practices applicable to the critical infrastructure materials operations, unless that use bears a direct relationship to public health or safety.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(2): 76-10-803; 4-44-201 In a civil action for nuisance or a criminal action for public nuisance under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(2)(a): those agricultural activities were:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(2)(a)(i): conducted within an agriculture protection area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(2)(a)(ii): not in violation of any federal, state, or local law or regulation relating to the alleged nuisance or were conducted according to sound agricultural practices; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(2)(b): 4-44-201 a defense under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(3): 76-10-803
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(3)(a): A vested mining use undertaken in conformity with applicable federal and state law and regulations is presumed to be operating within sound mining practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(3)(b): 76-10-803 A vested mining use that is consistent with sound mining practices:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(3)(b)(i): is presumed to be reasonable; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(3)(b)(ii): 76-10-803 may not constitute a private or public nuisance under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(3)(c): A vested mining use in operation for more than three years may not be considered to have become a private or public nuisance because of a subsequent change in the condition of land within the vicinity of the vested mining use.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(4)(a): For any new subdivision development located in whole or in part within 300 feet of the boundary of an agriculture protection area, the owner of the development shall provide notice on any plat filed with the county recorder the following notice:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-403(4)(b): For any new subdivision development located in whole or in part within 1,000 feet of the boundary of an industrial protection area, the owner of the development shall provide notice on any plat filed with the county recorder the following notice:

Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-404 Policy of state agencies.
---------------------------------------------------------
A state agency shall encourage the continuity, development, and viability of agriculture within agriculture protection areas, industrial uses with industrial protection areas, and critical infrastructure materials operations within critical infrastructure protection areas by:Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-404(1): not enacting rules that would impose unreasonable restrictions on farm structures or farm practices within the agriculture protection area, on industrial uses and practices within the industrial protection area, or on critical infrastructure materials operations with a critical infrastructure materials protection area, unless those laws, ordinances, or regulations bear a direct relationship to public health or safety or are required by federal law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-404(2): modifying existing rules that would impose unreasonable restrictions on farm structures or farm practices within the agriculture protection area, on industrial uses and activities within the industrial protection area, or on critical infrastructure materials operations within a critical infrastructure materials protection area, unless those laws, ordinances, or regulations bear a direct relationship to public health or safety or are required by federal law.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405 Eminent domain restrictions -- Notice of hearing.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(1): A political subdivision having or exercising eminent domain powers may not condemn for any purpose any land within an agriculture protection area that is being used for agricultural production, land within an industrial protection area that is being put to an industrial use, or land within a critical infrastructure materials protection area, unless the political subdivision obtains approval, according to the procedures and requirements of this section, from the applicable legislative body and the advisory board.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(2): Any condemnor wishing to condemn property within an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area shall file a notice of condemnation with the applicable legislative body and the relevant protection area's advisory board at least 30 days before filing an eminent domain complaint.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(3): 63G-30-102 The applicable legislative body and the advisory board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(3)(a): hold a joint public hearing on the proposed condemnation at a location within the county in which the relevant protection area is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(3)(b): 63G-30-102 publish notice of the time, date, place, and purpose of the public hearing for the relevant protection area, as a class A notice under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(4)(a): If the condemnation is for highway purposes or for the disposal of solid or liquid waste materials, the applicable legislative body and the advisory board may approve the condemnation only if there is no reasonable and prudent alternative to the use of the land within the agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area for the project.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(4)(b): If the condemnation is for any other purpose, the applicable legislative body and the advisory board may approve the condemnation only if:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(4)(b)(i): the proposed condemnation would not have an unreasonably adverse effect upon the preservation and enhancement of:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(4)(b)(i)(A): agriculture within the agriculture protection area;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(4)(b)(i)(B): the industrial use within the industrial protection area; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(4)(b)(i)(C): critical infrastructure materials operations within the critical infrastructure materials protection area; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(4)(b)(ii): there is no reasonable and prudent alternative to the use of the land within the relevant protection area for the project.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(5): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(5)(a): Within 60 days after receipt of the notice of condemnation, the applicable legislative body and the advisory board shall approve or reject the proposed condemnation.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(5)(b): If the applicable legislative body and the advisory board fail to act within the 60 days or such further time as the applicable legislative body establishes, the condemnation shall be considered rejected.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-405(6): The applicable legislative body or the advisory board may request the county or municipal attorney to bring an action to enjoin any condemnor from violating any provisions of this section.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406 Restrictions on state development projects.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406(1): A state agency that plans any development project that might affect land within an agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area, shall submit the state agency's development plan to:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406(1)(a): the advisory board of the relevant protection area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406(1)(b): in the case of an agriculture protection area, the commissioner of agriculture and food.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406(2): The commissioner of agriculture and food, in the case of an agriculture protection area, and the advisory board shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406(2)(a): review the state agency's proposed development plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406(2)(b): recommend any modifications to the development project that would protect the integrity of the agriculture protection area, industrial protection area, or critical infrastructure materials protection area, as the case may be, or that would protect the agriculture protection area from nonfarm encroachment, the industrial protection area from nonindustrial encroachment, or the critical infrastructure materials protection area from encroachment of uses unrelated to critical infrastructure materials operations.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406(3): A state agency and political subdivision of the state that designates or proposes to designate a transportation corridor shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406(3)(a): consider:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406(3)(a)(i): whether the transportation corridor would:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406(3)(a)(i)(A): be located on land that is included within an agriculture protection area; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406(3)(a)(i)(B): interfere with agriculture production activities on land within an agriculture protection area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406(3)(a)(ii): each other reasonably comparable alternative to the placement of the corridor on land within an agriculture protection area; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-406(3)(b): make reasonable efforts to minimize or eliminate any detrimental impact on agriculture that may result from the designation of a transportation corridor.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501 Vested mining use -- Conclusive presumption.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(1)(a): A mining use is conclusively presumed to be a vested mining use if the mining use existed or was conducted or otherwise engaged in before a political subdivision prohibits, restricts, or otherwise limits the mining use.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(1)(b): Anyone claiming that a vested mining use has not been established has the burden of proof to show by clear and convincing evidence that the vested mining use has not been established.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(2): A vested mining use:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(2)(a): runs with the land; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(2)(b): may be changed to another mining use without losing its status as a vested mining use.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(3): The present or future boundary described in the large mine permit of a mine operator with a vested mining use does not limit:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(3)(a): the scope of the mine operator's rights under this chapter; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(3)(b): the protection that this chapter provides for a mining protection area.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(4): (4)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(4)(a): A mine operator with a vested mining use shall file a declaration for recording in the office of the recorder of the county in which the vested mining use is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(4)(b): (4)(a) A declaration under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(4)(b)(i): contain a legal description of the land included within the vested mining use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-501(4)(b)(ii): provide notice of the vested mining use.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502 Rights of a mine operator with a vested mining use -- Expanding vested mining use.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(1): Notwithstanding a political subdivision's prohibition, restriction, or other limitation on a mining use adopted after the establishment of the mining use, the rights of a mine operator with a vested mining use include the rights to:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(1)(a): progress, extend, enlarge, grow, or expand the vested mining use to any surface or subsurface land or mineral estate that the mine operator owns or controls;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(1)(b): expand the vested mining use to any new land that:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(1)(b)(i): is contiguous and related in mineralization to surface or subsurface land or a mineral estate that the mine operator already owns or controls;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(1)(b)(ii): contains minerals that are part of the same mineral trend as the minerals that the mine operator already owns or controls; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(1)(b)(iii): is a geologic offshoot to surface or subsurface land or a mineral estate that the mine operator already owns or controls;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(1)(c): use, operate, construct, reconstruct, restore, extend, expand, maintain, repair, alter, substitute, modernize, upgrade, and replace equipment, processes, facilities, and buildings on any surface or subsurface land or mineral estate that the mine operator owns or controls;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(1)(d): increase production or volume, alter the method of mining or processing, and mine or process a different or additional mineral than previously mined or owned on any surface or subsurface land or mineral estate that the mine operator owns or controls; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(1)(e): discontinue, suspend, terminate, deactivate, or continue and reactivate, temporarily or permanently, all or any part of the mining use.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2): (2); (2)(c); (2)(d)(i); (2)(d)(ii)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(a): (2) As used in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(a)(i): county in whose unincorporated area the new land to be included in the vested mining use is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(a)(ii): municipality in which the new land to be included in the vested mining use is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(b): A mine operator with a vested mining use is presumed to have a right to expand the vested mining use to new land.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(c): Before expanding a vested mining use to new land, a mine operator shall provide written notice:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(c)(i): of the mine operator's intent to expand the vested mining use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(c)(ii): to each applicable legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(d): (2)(c); (2)(d)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(d)(i): (2)(c) An applicable legislative body shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(d)(i)(A): (2)(c) hold a public meeting or hearing at its next available meeting that is more than 10 days after receiving the notice under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(d)(i)(B): provide reasonable, advance, written notice:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(d)(i)(B)(I): of:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(d)(i)(B)(I)(Aa): the intended expansion of the vested mining use; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(d)(i)(B)(I)(Bb): the public meeting or hearing; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(d)(i)(B)(II): to each owner of the surface estate of the new land.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(d)(ii): (2)(d)(i) A public meeting or hearing under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(2)(e): (2)(d)(ii) After the public meeting or hearing under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(3): If a mine operator expands a vested mining use to new land, as authorized under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(3)(a): the mine operator's rights under the vested mining use with respect to land on which the vested mining use occurs apply with equal force after the expansion to the new land; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-502(3)(b): the mining protection area that includes land on which the vested mining use occurs is expanded to include the new land.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this part:Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(1): 59-2-502 "Agricultural land" means "land in agricultural use," as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(2): (2)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(2)(a): "Open land" means land that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(2)(a)(i): preserved in or restored to a predominantly natural, open, and undeveloped condition; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(2)(a)(ii): used for:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(2)(a)(ii)(A): wildlife habitat;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(2)(a)(ii)(B): cultural or recreational use;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(2)(a)(ii)(C): watershed protection; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(2)(a)(ii)(D): another use consistent with the preservation of the land in, or restoration of the land to, a predominantly natural, open, and undeveloped condition.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(2)(b): (2)(a) "Open land" includes land described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(2)(b)(i): enhance the natural, scenic, or aesthetic qualities of the land; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(2)(b)(ii): facilitate the public's access to, or use of, the land for the enjoyment of the land's natural, scenic, or aesthetic qualities and for compatible recreational activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(2)(c): "Open land" does not include land whose predominant use is as a developed facility for active recreational activities played on fields or courses, including baseball, tennis, soccer, golf, or other sporting or similar activities.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(3): "Public land county" means a county in which over 50% of the land area is publicly owned.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-41-601(4): 59-2-506; 59-2-511; 59-2-1705; 59-2-1710 "Rollback tax funds" means the rollback taxes paid to a county in accordance with Sections

Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-202 Local substance abuse authorities -- Requirements prior to distributing public funds.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-202(1): Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code Each local substance abuse authority shall award all public funds in compliance with:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-202(1)(a): Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code the requirements of
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-202(1)(b): a county procurement ordinance that requires similar procurement practices.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-202(2): If all initial bids on the project are rejected, the authority shall publish a new invitation to bid.  If no satisfactory bid is received by the authority when the bids received from the second invitation are opened, the authority may execute a contract without requiring competitive bidding.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-202(3): A local substance abuse authority need not comply with the procurement provisions of this section when it disburses public funds to another political subdivision of the state or an institution of higher education of the state.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-202(4): Each contract awarded by a local substance abuse authority shall be for a fixed amount and limited period.  A contract may be modified due to changes in available funding for the same contract purpose without competition.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203 Definition of "public funds" -- Responsibility for oversight of public funds -- Substance abuse programs and services.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(1): As used in this section, "public funds":
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(1)(a): means:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(1)(a)(i): federal money received from the Department of Health and Human Services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(1)(a)(ii): state money appropriated by the Legislature to the Department of Health and Human Services, a county governing body, or a local substance abuse authority for the purposes of providing substance abuse programs or services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(1)(b): includes that federal and state money:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(1)(b)(i): even after the money has been transferred by a local substance abuse authority to a private provider under an annual or otherwise ongoing contract to provide comprehensive substance abuse programs or services for the local substance abuse authority; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(1)(b)(ii): while in the possession of the private provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(2): Each local substance abuse authority is responsible for oversight of all public funds received by it, to determine that those public funds are utilized in accordance with federal and state law, the rules and policies of the Department of Health and Human Services, and the provisions of any contract between the local substance abuse authority and the Department of Health and Human Services or a private provider.  That oversight includes requiring that neither the contract provider, as described in Subsection (1), nor any of its employees:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(2)(a): violate any applicable federal or state criminal law;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(2)(b): knowingly violate any applicable rule or policy of the Department of Health and Human Services, or knowingly violate any provision of contract between the local substance abuse authority and the Department of Health and Human Services or the private provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(2)(c): knowingly keep any false account or make any false entry or erasure in any account of or relating to the public funds;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(2)(d): fraudulently alter, falsify, conceal, destroy, or obliterate any account of or relating to public funds;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(2)(e): fail to ensure competent oversight for lawful disbursement of public funds;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(2)(f): appropriate public funds for an unlawful use or for a use that is not in compliance with contract provisions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(2)(g): knowingly or intentionally use public funds unlawfully or in violation of a governmental contract provision, or in violation of state policy.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(3): Each local substance abuse authority that knows or reasonably should know of any of the circumstances described in Subsection (2), and that fails or refuses to take timely corrective action in good faith shall, in addition to any other penalties provided by law, be required to make full and complete repayment to the state of all public funds improperly used or expended.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-203(4): Any public funds required to be repaid to the state by a local substance abuse authority under Subsection (3), based upon the actions or failure of the contract provider, may be recovered by the local substance abuse authority from its contract provider, in addition to the local substance abuse authority's costs and attorney's fees.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303 Definition of "public funds" -- Responsibility for oversight of public funds -- Mental health programs and services.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(1): As used in this section, "public funds":
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(1)(a): means:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(1)(a)(i): federal money received from the department or the Department of Health and Human Services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(1)(a)(ii): state money appropriated by the Legislature to the department, the Department of Health and Human Services, a county governing body, or a local mental health authority for the purposes of providing mental health programs or services; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(1)(b): includes that federal and state money:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(1)(b)(i): even after the money has been transferred by a local mental health authority to a private provider under an annual or otherwise ongoing contract to provide  comprehensive mental health programs or services for the local mental health authority; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(1)(b)(ii): while in the possession of the private provider.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(2): (1) Each local mental health authority is responsible for oversight of all public funds received by it, to determine that those public funds are utilized in accordance with federal and state law, the rules and policies of the department and the Department of Health and Human Services, and the provisions of any contract between the local mental health authority and the department, the Department of Health and Human Services, or a private provider.  That oversight includes requiring that neither the contract provider, as described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(2)(a): violate any applicable federal or state criminal law;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(2)(b): knowingly violate any applicable rule or policy of the department or Department of Health and Human Services, or any provision of contract between the local mental health authority and the department, the Department of Health and Human Services, or the private provider;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(2)(c): knowingly keep any false account or make any false entry or erasure in any account of or relating to the public funds;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(2)(d): fraudulently alter, falsify, conceal, destroy, or obliterate any account of or relating to public funds;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(2)(e): fail to ensure competent oversight for lawful disbursement of public funds;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(2)(f): appropriate public funds for an unlawful use or for a use that is not in compliance with contract provisions; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(2)(g): knowingly or intentionally use public funds unlawfully or in violation of a governmental contract provision, or in violation of state policy.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(3): (2) A local mental health authority that knew or reasonably should have known of any of the circumstances described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-303(4): (3) Any public funds required to be repaid to the state by a local mental health authority pursuant to Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-304 Contracts for mental health services provided by local mental health authorities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
If a local mental health authority has established a plan to provide services authorized by this part, and those services meet standards fixed by rules of the division, the local mental health authority may enter into a contract with the division for those services to be furnished by that local mental health authority for an agreed compensation to be paid by the division.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-308 Specified treatments prohibited -- Criminal penalties.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-308(1): Title 58, Chapter 67, Utah Medical Practice Act It is a class B misdemeanor to give shock treatment, lobotomy, or surgery to anyone without the written consent of the person's next of kin or legal guardian. Services provided under this part are governed by
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-308(2): It is a felony to give psychiatric treatment, nonvocational mental health counseling, case-finding testing, psychoanalysis, drugs, shock treatment, lobotomy, or surgery to any individual for the purpose of changing his concept of, belief about, or faith in God.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-309 Local mental health advisory councils -- Powers and responsibilities.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-309(1): A county legislative body may, separately or in conjunction with one or more other counties, establish a local mental health advisory council.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-309(2): Mental health advisory council members shall be appointed by their respective county legislative bodies.  Initially one-fourth of the members shall be appointed for one year, one-fourth for two years, one-fourth for three years, and one-fourth for four years.  After the initial appointment, the term of each member shall be for four years.  Vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as for unexpired terms.  Council members may be removed for cause.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-309(3): Each mental health advisory council shall be responsible and advisory to local mental health authorities in planning, organizing, and operating community mental health programs.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-309(4): Council members shall be selected from persons representative of interested groups in the community, including, if possible:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-309(4)(a): an officer or employee of the school district within the city or county;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-309(4)(b): one or more persons familiar with problems in mental health, as these are involved in proceedings in criminal, domestic, or juvenile courts;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-309(4)(c): one or more members of voluntary health, welfare, or mental health associations or agencies;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-309(4)(d): a member of the legislative body of each participating county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-309(4)(e): at least one person licensed in this state to practice medicine and surgery in all their branches and engaged in the private practice of medicine.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-309(5): Council members may be reimbursed for actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of official duties, from funds made available to local mental health authorities.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-43-309(6): Each mental health advisory council shall be an agent of the local mental health authority, and is subject to laws and requirements relating to the local mental health authority.

Utah Code Annotated - Title 17 - Chapter 50 - General Provisions for Counties
*****************************************************************************

Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-101 Definitions.
--------------------------------------------
As used in this title:Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-101(1): 17-50-104; Part 3, County Powers "County" means a unit of local government that is a body corporate and politic and a legal subdivision of the state, with geographic boundaries as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-101(2): "Executive," when used to describe the powers, duties, or functions of a person or body elected as the county executive or a person appointed as the county manager or administrative officer, refers to:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-101(2)(a): the power and duty to carry laws and ordinances into effect and secure their due observance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-101(2)(b): those powers, duties, and functions that, under constitutional and statutory provisions and through long usage and accepted practice and custom at the federal and state level, have come to be regarded as belonging to the executive branch of government.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-101(3): "Legislative," when used to describe the powers, duties, or functions of a county commission or council, refers to:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-101(3)(a): the power and duty to enact ordinances, levy taxes, and establish budgets; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-101(3)(b): those powers, duties, and functions that, under constitutional and statutory provisions and through long usage and accepted practice and custom at the federal and state level, have come to be regarded as belonging to the legislative branch of government.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-102 Unlawful liabilities void.
----------------------------------------------------------
Each contract, authorization, allowance, payment, and purported liability to pay made or attempted to be made in violation of this title shall be absolutely void and shall never be the foundation or basis of a claim against the county.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103 Use of "county" prohibited -- Legal action to compel compliance.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(1): For purposes of this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(1)(a): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(1)(a)(i): "Existing local entity" means a special district, special service district, or other political subdivision of the state created before May 1, 2000.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(1)(a)(ii): "Existing local entity" does not include a county, city, town, or school district.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(1)(b)(i): "New local entity" means a city, town, school district, special district, special service district, or other political subdivision of the state created on or after May 1, 2000.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(1)(b)(ii): "New local entity" does not include a county.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(1)(c)(i): "Special district" means a special district under Title 17B, Limited Purpose Local Government Entities - Special Districts, that:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(1)(c)(i)(A): by statute is a political and corporate entity separate from the county that created the special district; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(1)(c)(i)(B): by statute is not subject to the direction and control of the county that created the special district.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(1)(c)(ii): The county legislative body's statutory authority to appoint members to the governing body of a special district does not alone make the special district subject to the direction and control of that county.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(2)(a): A new local entity may not use the word "county" in its name.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(2)(b): After January 1, 2005, an existing local entity may not use the word "county" in its name unless the county whose name is used by the existing local entity gives its written consent.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-103(3): A county with a name similar to the name of a new local entity or existing local entity in violation of this section may bring legal action in a court with jurisdiction under Title 78A, Judiciary and Judicial Administration, to compel compliance with this section.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-301 Exercise of county powers.
----------------------------------------------------------
The powers of a county may be exercised only by the county executive and county legislative body or by agents and officers acting under their authority or under authority of law.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-304 Police, building, and sanitary regulations.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
A county may make and enforce within the limits of the county, outside the limits of cities and towns, all such local, police, building, and sanitary regulations as are not in conflict with general laws.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-305 County powers to acquire, construct, and control roads and other facilities -- Retainage.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-305(1): A county may:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-305(1)(a): contract for, purchase, or otherwise acquire, when necessary, rights of way for county roads over private property, and may institute proceedings for acquiring such rights of way as provided by law;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-305(1)(b): lay out, construct, maintain, control, and manage county roads, sidewalks, ferries and bridges within the county, outside of cities and towns;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-305(1)(c): designate the county roads to be maintained by the county within or extending through any city or town, which may not be more than three in the same direction;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-305(1)(d): abolish or abandon county roads that are unnecessary for the use of the public, in the manner provided by law; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-305(1)(e): lay out, construct, maintain, control, and manage landing fields and hangars for the use of airplanes or other vehicles for aerial travel.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-308 Franchises for ferries and bridges.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-308(1): A county may grant licenses and franchises for constructing and keeping in repair roads, bridges, and ferries and for the taking of tolls on them.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-308(2): Each person operating any toll boat or ferry for the transportation of persons, vehicles, or livestock across any stream, river, or body of water in this state shall obtain a franchise for its operation from the county executive of the county in which such boat or ferry is operated.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-308(3): If such boat or ferry is operated on a stream or body of water forming the boundary line between two adjoining counties, the person operating the boat or ferry shall obtain a franchise from the county executive of each county.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-309 Regulation of use of roads.
-----------------------------------------------------------
A county may enact ordinances and make regulations not in conflict with law for the control, construction, alteration, repair, and use of all public roads and highways in the county outside of cities and towns.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-320 Support of the arts by counties -- Guidelines.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A county may provide for and appropriate funds for the support of the arts, including music, dance, theatre, crafts and visual, folk and literary art, for the purpose of enriching the lives of its residents and may establish guidelines for the support of the arts.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-321 Implements of husbandry tracking debris onto county roads.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A county may not prohibit or punish the tracking of dirt, mud, or other debris onto county roads resulting from the operation of an implement of husbandry if the operation of the implement of husbandry is consistent with accepted agricultural practices.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-328(1)(c)(iii)(A): the county in whose unincorporated area the former mobile home park property is located; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-328(1)(c)(iii)(B): another taxing entity.
