Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5 Regulation of drive-through facilities.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(1): 17-27a-103 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(1)(a): "Business" means a private enterprise carried on for the purpose of gain or economic profit.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(1)(b): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(1)(b)(i): "Business lobby" means a public area, including a lobby, dining area, or other area accessible to the public where business is conducted within a place of business.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(1)(b)(ii): "Business lobby" does not include the area of a business where drive-through service is conducted.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(1)(c): 17-27a-103 "Land use application" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(1)(d): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(1)(d)(i): "Motor vehicle" means a self-propelled vehicle, including a motorcycle, intended primarily for use and operation on the highways.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(1)(d)(ii): "Motor vehicle" does not include an off-highway vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(1)(e): "Motorcycle" means a motor vehicle having a saddle for the use of the operator and designed to travel on not more than two tires.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(1)(f): "Off-highway vehicle" means any snowmobile, all-terrain type I vehicle, all-terrain type II vehicle, or all-terrain type III vehicle.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(2): A county may not withhold a business license, deny a land use application, or otherwise require a business that has a drive-through service as a component of its business operations to:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(2)(a): allow a person other than a person in a motorized vehicle to use the drive-through service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-329.5(2)(b): offer designated hours of the day that a customer is accommodated and business is conducted in the business lobby that are the same as or exceed the hours of the day that a customer is accommodated and business is conducted in the drive-through service.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-330 Prohibition against spending certain transportation funds.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-330(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-330(1)(a): "Apportioned" means divided or assigned among the states based on a prescribed formula established in 23 U.S.C.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-330(1)(b): "Authorization act" means an act of Congress enacted after July 1, 2009 that authorizes transportation programs from the Highway Trust Fund established in 26 U.S.C. Sec. 9503.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-330(2): A county may not spend project-specific funds that are allocated through an authorization act for a transportation-related project that is eligible for funds apportioned to the state in support of the statewide transportation improvement program unless the specified project is included on the statewide transportation improvement program.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331 Regulation of sexually oriented business.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1): As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(a): "Adult service" means dancing, serving food or beverages, modeling, posing, wrestling, singing, reading, talking, listening, or other performances or activities conducted by a nude or partially denuded individual for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(b): "Compensation" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(b)(i): a salary;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(b)(ii): a fee;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(b)(iii): a commission;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(b)(iv): employment;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(b)(v): a profit; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(b)(vi): other pecuniary gain.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(i): "Escort" means a person who, for compensation, dates, socializes with, visits, consorts with, or accompanies another, or offers to date, consort with, socialize with, visit, or accompany another:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(i)(A): to a social affair, entertainment, or a place of amusement; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(i)(B): within:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(i)(B)(I): a place of public or private resort;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(i)(B)(II): a business or commercial establishment; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(i)(B)(III): a private quarter.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(ii): "Escort" does not mean a person who provides business or personal services, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(ii)(A): a licensed private nurse;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(ii)(B): an aide for the elderly or a person with a disability;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(ii)(C): a social secretary or similar service personnel:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(ii)(C)(I): whose relationship with a patron is characterized by a contractual relationship having a duration of 12 hours or more; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(ii)(C)(II): who provides a service not principally characterized as dating or socializing; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(ii)(D): a person who provides services such as singing telegrams, birthday greetings, or similar activities:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(ii)(D)(I): characterized by an appearance in a public place;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(ii)(D)(II): contracted for by a party other than the person for whom the service is being performed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(c)(ii)(D)(III): of a duration not to exceed one hour.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(d): "Escort service" means any person who furnishes or arranges for an escort to accompany another individual for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(e): "Nude or partially denuded individual" means an individual with any of the following less than completely and opaquely covered:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(e)(i): genitals;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(e)(ii): the pubic region; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(e)(iii): a female breast below a point immediately above the top of the areola.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(f): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(f)(i): "Sexually oriented business" means a business at which any nude or partially denuded individual, regardless of whether the nude or partially denuded individual is an employee of the sexually oriented business or an independent contractor, performs any service for compensation.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(f)(ii): "Sexually oriented business" includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(f)(ii)(A): an escort service; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(1)(f)(ii)(B): an adult service.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(2): A person employed in a sexually oriented business may not work in the unincorporated area of a county:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(2)(a): if the county requires that a person employed in a sexually oriented business be licensed individually; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(2)(b): if the person is not licensed by the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(3): A business entity that conducts a sexually oriented business may not conduct business in an unincorporated area of a county:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(3)(a): if the county requires that a sexually oriented business be licensed; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-331(3)(b): if the business entity is not licensed by the county.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-332 Knives regulated by state.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-332(1): As used in this section, "knife" means a cutting instrument that includes a sharpened or pointed blade.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-332(2): The authority to regulate a knife is reserved to the state except where the Legislature specifically delegates responsibility to a county.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-332(3): (3)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-332(3)(a): (3)(b) Unless specifically authorized by the Legislature or, subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-332(3)(b): A county may not enact an ordinance with a criminal penalty pertaining to a knife that is:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-332(3)(b)(i): more restrictive than a state criminal penalty pertaining to a knife; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-332(3)(b)(ii): has a greater criminal penalty than a state penalty pertaining to a knife.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333 Regulation of retail tobacco specialty business.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1): 26B-1-201; 76-10-101; 26A-1-102; 76-10-101; 76-10-105.1; 76-10-101; 76-10-101 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(a): "Community location" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(a)(i): a public or private kindergarten, elementary, middle, junior high, or high school;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(a)(ii): a licensed child-care facility or preschool;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(a)(iii): a trade or technical school;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(a)(iv): a church;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(a)(v): a public library;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(a)(vi): a public playground;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(a)(vii): a public park;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(a)(viii): a youth center or other space used primarily for youth oriented activities;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(a)(ix): a public recreational facility;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(a)(x): a public arcade; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(a)(xi): for a new license issued on or after July 1, 2018, a homeless shelter.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(b): 26B-1-201 "Department" means the Department of Health and Human Services created in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(c): 76-10-101 "Electronic cigarette product" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(d): "Licensee" means a person licensed under this section to conduct business as a retail tobacco specialty business.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(e): 26A-1-102 "Local health department" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(f): 76-10-101 "Nicotine product" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(g): "Retail tobacco specialty business" means a commercial establishment in which:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(g)(i): sales of tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, and nicotine products account for more than 35% of the total quarterly gross receipts for the establishment;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(g)(ii): 20% or more of the public retail floor space is allocated to the offer, display, or storage of tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(g)(iii): 20% or more of the total shelf space is allocated to the offer, display, or storage of tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(g)(iv): the commercial establishment:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(g)(iv)(A): holds itself out as a retail tobacco specialty business; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(g)(iv)(B): causes a reasonable person to believe the commercial establishment is a retail tobacco specialty business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(g)(v): the retail space features a self-service display for tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(h): 76-10-105.1 "Self-service display" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(i): 76-10-101; 76-10-101 "Tobacco product" means:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(i)(i): 76-10-101 the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(1)(i)(ii): 76-10-101 tobacco paraphernalia as defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(2): The regulation of a retail tobacco specialty business is an exercise of the police powers of the state by the state or by the delegation of the state's police power to other governmental entities.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(3): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(3)(a): A person may not operate a retail tobacco specialty business in a county unless the person obtains a license from the county in which the retail tobacco specialty business is located.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(3)(b): A county may only issue a retail tobacco specialty business license to a person if the person complies with the provisions of Subsections (4) and (5).
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(4)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (7), a county may not issue a license for a person to conduct business as a retail tobacco specialty business if the retail tobacco specialty business is located within:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(4)(a)(i): 1,000 feet of a community location;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(4)(a)(ii): 600 feet of another retail tobacco specialty business; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(4)(a)(iii): 600 feet from property used or zoned for:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(4)(a)(iii)(A): agriculture use; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(4)(a)(iii)(B): residential use.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(4)(b): For purposes of Subsection (4)(a), the proximity requirements shall be measured in a straight line from the nearest entrance of the retail tobacco specialty business to the nearest property boundary of a location described in Subsections (4)(a)(i) through (iii), without regard to intervening structures or zoning districts.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(5): 59-14-201; 59-14-301; 59-14-803 A county may not issue or renew a license for a person to conduct business as a retail tobacco specialty business until the person provides the county with proof that the retail tobacco specialty business has:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(5)(a): a valid permit for a retail tobacco specialty business issued under Title 26B, Chapter 7, Part 5, Regulation of Smoking, Tobacco Products, and Nicotine Products, by the local health department having jurisdiction over the area in which the retail tobacco specialty business is located; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(5)(b): 59-14-201; 59-14-301; 59-14-803
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(5)(b)(i): 59-14-201; 59-14-301 for a retailer that sells a tobacco product, a valid license issued by the State Tax Commission in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(5)(b)(ii): 59-14-803 for a retailer that sells an electronic cigarette product or a nicotine product, a valid license issued by the State Tax Commission in accordance with Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(6): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(6)(a): Nothing in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(6)(a)(i): requires a county to issue a retail tobacco specialty business license; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(6)(a)(ii): prohibits a county from adopting more restrictive requirements on a person seeking a license or renewal of a license to conduct business as a retail tobacco specialty business.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(6)(b): A county may suspend or revoke a retail tobacco specialty business license issued under this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(6)(b)(i): if a licensee engages in a pattern of unlawful activity under Title 76, Chapter 10, Part 16, Pattern of Unlawful Activity Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(6)(b)(ii): if a licensee violates federal law or federal regulations restricting the sale and distribution of tobacco products or electronic cigarette products to protect children and adolescents;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(6)(b)(iii): upon the recommendation of the department or a local health department under Title 26B, Chapter 7, Part 5, Regulation of Smoking, Tobacco Products, and Nicotine Products; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(6)(b)(iv): under any other provision of state law or local ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(a): Except as provided in Subsection (7)(e), a retail tobacco specialty business is exempt from Subsection (4) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(a)(i): on or before December 31, 2018, the retail tobacco specialty business was issued a license to conduct business as a retail tobacco specialty business;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(a)(ii): the retail tobacco specialty business is operating in a county in accordance with all applicable laws except for the requirement in Subsection (4); and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(a)(iii): beginning July 1, 2022, the retail tobacco specialty business is not located within 1,000 feet of a public or private kindergarten, elementary, middle, junior high, or high school.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(b): A retail tobacco specialty business may maintain an exemption under Subsection (7)(a) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(b)(i): the license described in Subsection (7)(a)(i) is renewed continuously without lapse or permanent revocation;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(b)(ii): the retail tobacco specialty business does not close for business or otherwise suspend the sale of tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products for more than 60 consecutive days;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(b)(iii): the retail tobacco specialty business does not substantially change the business premises or business operation; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(b)(iv): the retail tobacco specialty business maintains the right to operate under the terms of other applicable laws, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(b)(iv)(A): Title 26, Chapter 38, Utah Indoor Clean Air Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(b)(iv)(B): zoning ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(b)(iv)(C): building codes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(b)(iv)(D): the requirements of the license described in Subsection (7)(a)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(c): A retail tobacco specialty business that does not qualify for an exemption under Subsection (7)(a) is exempt from Subsection (4) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(c)(i): on or before December 31, 2018, the retail tobacco specialty business was issued a general tobacco retailer permit or a retail tobacco specialty business permit under Title 26, Chapter 62, Tobacco, Electronic Cigarette, and Nicotine Product Retail Permit, by the local health department having jurisdiction over the area in which the retail tobacco specialty business is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(c)(ii): the retail tobacco specialty business is operating in the county in accordance with all applicable laws except for the requirement in Subsection (4); and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(c)(iii): beginning July 1, 2022, the retail tobacco specialty business is not located within 1,000 feet of a public or private kindergarten, elementary, middle, junior high, or high school.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(d): A retail tobacco specialty business may maintain an exemption under Subsection (7)(c) if:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(d)(i): on or before December 31, 2020, the retail tobacco specialty business receives a retail tobacco specialty business permit from the local health department having jurisdiction over the area in which the retail tobacco specialty business is located;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(d)(ii): the permit described in Subsection (7)(d)(i) is renewed continuously without lapse or permanent revocation;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(d)(iii): the retail tobacco specialty business does not close for business or otherwise suspend the sale of tobacco products, electronic cigarette products, or nicotine products for more than 60 consecutive days;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(d)(iv): the retail tobacco specialty business does not substantially change the business premises or business operation as the business existed when the retail tobacco specialty business received a permit under Subsection (7)(d)(i); and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(d)(v): the retail tobacco specialty business maintains the right to operate under the terms of other applicable laws, including:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(d)(v)(A): Title 26, Chapter 38, Utah Indoor Clean Air Act;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(d)(v)(B): zoning ordinances;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(d)(v)(C): building codes; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(d)(v)(D): the requirements of the retail tobacco permit described in Subsection (7)(d)(i).
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(e): A retail tobacco specialty business described in Subsection (7)(a) or (b) that is located within 1,000 feet of a public or private kindergarten, elementary, middle, junior high, or high school before July 1, 2022, is exempt from Subsection (4)(a)(iii)(B) if the retail tobacco specialty business:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(e)(i): relocates, before July 1, 2022, to a property that is used or zoned for commercial use and located within a group of architecturally unified commercial establishments built on a site that is planned, developed, owned, and managed as an operating unit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-333(7)(e)(ii): continues to meet the requirements described in Subsection (7)(b) that are not directly related to the relocation described in this Subsection (7)(e).

Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-338 Ordinances regarding short-term rentals -- Prohibition on ordinances restricting speech on short-term rental websites.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-338(1): 10-9a-511.5 As used in this section:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-338(1)(a): 10-9a-511.5 "Internal accessory dwelling unit" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-338(1)(b): "Residential unit" means a residential structure or any portion of a residential structure that is occupied as a residence.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-338(1)(c): "Short-term rental" means a residential unit or any portion of a residential unit that the owner of record or the lessee of the residential unit offers for occupancy for fewer than 30 consecutive days.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-338(1)(d): "Short-term rental website" means a website that:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-338(1)(d)(i): allows a person to offer a short-term rental to one or more prospective renters; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-338(1)(d)(ii): facilitates the renting of, and payment for, a short-term rental.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-338(2): 17-27a-501; 17-27a-503(1) Notwithstanding Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-338(2)(a): enact or enforce an ordinance that prohibits an individual from listing or offering a short-term rental on a short-term rental website; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-338(2)(b): use an ordinance that prohibits the act of renting a short-term rental to fine, charge, prosecute, or otherwise punish an individual solely for the act of listing or offering a short-term rental on a short-term rental website.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-338(3): (2); 17-27a-526(6) Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-340 Establishment of county recorder appeal authority.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-340(2)(a): does not preclude an individual who seeks an appeal from a county recorder's decision from pursuing any other available remedy; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-340(2)(b): (1) may not be construed as requiring an individual to exhaust administrative remedies with an appeal authority established under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-402 Payment or rejection of claims.
---------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-402(1): If the county executive finds that any claim presented is not payable by the county or is not a proper county charge, the county executive shall reject the claim.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-402(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-402(2)(a): If the claim is found to be a proper county charge, but greater in amount than is justly due, the county executive may allow the claim in part and may order a warrant drawn for the portion allowed.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-402(2)(b): If the claimant is unwilling to receive the amount in full payment, the county executive may again consider the claim.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-402(3): No claim may be paid if paying the claim would exceed the current unencumbered funds.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-403 Action on rejected claim -- Limitation.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-403(1): A claimant dissatisfied with the rejection of a claim or demand or with the amount allowed on an account may sue the county on the claim, demand, or account at any time within one year after the first rejection of the claim, demand, or account by the county executive, but not afterward.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-403(2): If in such action judgment is recovered for more than the county executive allowed, costs shall be taxed against the county, but if no more is recovered than the county executive allowed, costs shall be taxed against the plaintiff.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-403(3): On presentation of a certified copy of a judgment against the county, the county executive shall allow and pay the same.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-404 Judgments against county -- Payment.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-404(1): If a judgment is obtained against a county, it shall be paid as are other county charges.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-404(2): The county  legislative body shall levy and authorize the collection of a sufficient amount of revenue to pay off and discharge such judgment in addition to the ordinary expenses of the county, but the property of the county and of the persons owning property situated or liable to taxation in the county may not be liable to judgment lien or to seizure or sale upon execution or other process of any court.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-405 County legislative body claim for expenses -- County attorney's opinion of legality.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-405(1): Each claim against the county presented by a member of the county legislative body for the member's expenses shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-405(1)(a): be itemized and verified as other claims;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-405(1)(b): state that the service has been actually rendered; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-405(1)(c): be presented to the county attorney or, in a county that has a district attorney but not a county attorney, the district attorney.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-405(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-405(2)(a): The county or district attorney, as the case may be, shall endorse on the claim, in writing, the attorney's opinion as to its legality.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-405(2)(b): If the attorney declares the claim illegal, the attorney shall state specifically the reasons why it is illegal, and the county executive shall reject the claim.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-406 Officers not to advocate claims -- Right to oppose claims.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-406(1): No county officer may, except for the officer's own services, present any claim, account, or demand for allowance against the county or in any way advocate the relief asked in the claim or demand made by any other person.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-406(2): (1) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-406(3): Any person may appear before the county executive and oppose the allowance of any claim or demand made against the county.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-501 Classification of counties.
-----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-501(1): Each county shall be classified according to its population.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-501(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-501(2)(a): A county with a population of 1,000,000 or more is a county of the first class.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-501(2)(b): A county with a population of 175,000 or more but less than 1,000,000 is a county of the second class.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-501(2)(c): A county with a population of 40,000 or more but less than 175,000 is a county of the third class.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-501(2)(d): A county with a population of 11,000 or more but less than 40,000 is a county of the fourth class.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-501(2)(e): A county with a population of 4,000 or more but less than 11,000 is a county of the fifth class.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-501(2)(f): A county with a population less than 4,000 is a county of the sixth class.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-502 Change of class of county.
----------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-502(1): 17-50-501 Each county shall retain its classification under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-502(2): The lieutenant governor shall monitor the population figure for each county as shown on:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-502(2)(a): each official census or census estimate of the United States Bureau of the Census; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-502(2)(b): if the population figure for a county is not available from the United States Bureau of the Census, the population estimate from the Utah Population Committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-502(3): (2) After July 1, 2021, if the applicable population figure under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-502(3)(a): prepare a certificate indicating the class in which the county belongs based on the increased population figure; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-502(3)(b): within 10 days after preparing the certificate, deliver a copy of the certificate to the county legislative body and, if the county has an executive that is separate from the legislative body, the executive of the county whose class was changed.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-50-502(4): (3) A county's change in class is effective on the date of the lieutenant governor's certificate under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-201(6)(e)(i)(B): for the purposes of a regular general election, elected to fill the open positions; and

Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203 County executive-council form of county government.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203(1)(a): The following shall govern a county operating under the form of government known as the "county executive-council" form:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203(1)(a)(i): an elected county council;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203(1)(a)(ii): an elected county executive; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203(1)(a)(iii): other officers and employees authorized by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203(1)(b): The optional plan shall provide for the qualifications, time, and manner of election, term of office and compensation of the county executive.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203(2): The county executive is the chief executive officer or body of the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203(3): Chapter 53, Part 2, County Legislative Body; Chapter 53, Part 3, County Executive In the county executive-council form of county government:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203(3)(a): Chapter 53, Part 2, County Legislative Body the county council is the county legislative body and has the powers, duties, and functions of a county legislative body under
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203(3)(b): Chapter 53, Part 3, County Executive the county executive has the powers, duties, and functions of a county executive under
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203(4): References in any statute or state rule to the "governing body" or the "board of county commissioners" of the county, in the county executive-council form of county government, means:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203(4)(a): the county council, with respect to legislative functions, duties, and powers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-203(4)(b): the county executive, with respect to executive functions, duties, and powers.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204 Council-manager form of county government.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(1): (6); (7)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(1)(a): The following shall govern a county operating under the form of government known as the "council-manager" form:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(1)(a)(i): an elected county council;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(1)(a)(ii): a county manager appointed by the council; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(1)(a)(iii): other officers and employees authorized by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(1)(b): (6); (7) The optional plan shall provide for the qualifications, time and manner of appointment subject to Subsections
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(2): The county manager is the administrative head of the county government and has the powers, functions, and duties of a county executive, except:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(2)(a): as the county legislative body otherwise provides by ordinance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(2)(b): that the county manager may not veto any ordinances enacted by the council.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(3): (3); (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(3)(a): An individual member of the council may not directly or indirectly, by suggestion or otherwise:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(3)(a)(i): attempt to influence or coerce the manager in:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(3)(a)(i)(A): making any appointment;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(3)(a)(i)(B): removing any officer or employee; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(3)(a)(i)(C): purchasing supplies;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(3)(a)(ii): attempt to exact any promise relative to any appointment from any candidate for manager; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(3)(a)(iii): discuss directly or indirectly with the manager the matter of specific appointments to any county office or employment.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(3)(b): (3); (3)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(3)(b)(i): (3) A member of the county council who violates the provisions of this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(3)(b)(ii): Nothing in this section shall be construed, however, as prohibiting the council from fully and freely discussing with or suggesting to the manager anything pertaining to county affairs or the interests of the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(3)(b)(iii): The county manager may not take part in securing, or contributing any money toward, the nomination or election of any candidate for a county office.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(3)(b)(iv): (3) The optional plan may provide procedures for implementing this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(4): In the council-manager form of county government:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(4)(a): the legislative powers of the county are vested in the county council; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(4)(b): the executive powers of the county are vested in the county manager.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(5): A reference in statute or state rule to the "governing body" or the "board of county commissioners" of the county, in the council-manager form of county government, means:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(5)(a): the county council, with respect to legislative functions, duties, and powers; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(5)(b): the county manager, with respect to executive functions, duties, and powers.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(6): (6); 17-16-6; (6)(b)(i); (6)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(6)(a): (6); 17-16-6 As used in this Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(6)(a)(i): 17-16-6 begins on the day on which a general election described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(6)(a)(ii): ends on the day on which the council member-elect begins the council member's term.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(6)(b): (6)(b)(i)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(6)(b)(i): The county council may not appoint a county manager during an interim vacancy period.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(6)(b)(ii): (6)(b)(i) Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(6)(b)(ii)(A): the county council may appoint an interim county manager during an interim vacancy period; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(6)(b)(ii)(B): the interim county manager's term shall expire once a new county manager is appointed by the new administration after the interim vacancy period has ended.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(6)(c): (6)(b) Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-204(7): A county council that appoints a county manager in accordance with this section may not, on or after May 10, 2011, enter into an employment contract that contains an automatic renewal provision with the county manager.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-402(1): 17-52a-302; 17-52a-303 The county executive shall convene the first meeting of the study committee no later than 10 days after the day on which the county executive receives notification:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-402(1)(a): 17-52a-302 of the establishment of a study committee by the county legislative body as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-402(1)(b): 17-52a-303 of a certified petition from the county clerk as described in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-402(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-402(2)(a): At the study committee's first meeting, the study committee shall select a chair from among the members of the study committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-402(2)(b): The chair of the study committee is responsible for convening each future meeting of the study committee.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403 Study committee -- Members -- Powers and duties -- Proposed plan and report -- Services provided by county.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(1): 17-52a-302; 17-52a-303
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(1)(a): 17-52a-302; 17-52a-303 A study committee consists of:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(1)(a)(i): 17-52a-302 for a study committee established by the county legislative body under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(1)(a)(ii): 17-52a-303 for a study committee established by the registered voters through a petition under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(1)(a)(ii)(A): two members appointed by the sponsors of the petition;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(1)(a)(ii)(B): two members appointed by the county legislative body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(1)(a)(ii)(C): one member appointed by the county's council of governments.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(1)(b): A member of a study committee:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(1)(b)(i): may not receive compensation for service on the study committee;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(1)(b)(ii): may not hold an elected county office or have filed a current declaration of candidacy for an elected county office; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(1)(b)(iii): shall be a registered voter.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(1)(c): The county legislative body shall reimburse each member of a study committee for necessary expenses incurred in performing the member's duties on the study committee.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(2): A study committee may:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(2)(a): adopt rules for the study committee's own organization and procedure and to fill a vacancy in its membership;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(2)(b): establish advisory boards or committees and include on the advisory boards or committees persons who are not members of the study committee; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(2)(c): request the assistance and advice of any officers or employees of any agency of state or local government.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(3): 17-52a-402; (3)(a)(iv); 17-52a-406
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(3)(a): 17-52a-402 A study committee shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(3)(a)(i): study the form of government within the county and compare it with other forms available under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(3)(a)(ii): determine whether the administration of local government in the county could be strengthened, made more clearly responsive or accountable to the people, or significantly improved in the interest of economy and efficiency by a change in the form of county government;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(3)(a)(iii): hold public hearings and community forums and other means the committee considers appropriate to disseminate information and stimulate public discussion of the committee's purposes, progress, and conclusions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(3)(a)(iv): 17-52a-402 file a written report of the study committee's findings and recommendations with the county executive, the county legislative body, and the county clerk no later than one year after the convening of the study committee's first meeting under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(3)(b): (3)(a)(iv); 17-52a-406 Within 10 days after the day on which the study committee submits the study committee's report under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(4): (3)(a)(iv) Each study committee report under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(4)(a): the study committee's recommendation as to whether the form of county government should be changed to another form authorized under this chapter;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(4)(b): if the study committee recommends changing the form of government, a complete detailed draft of a proposed optional plan to change the form of county government, including all necessary implementing provisions; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(4)(c): any additional recommendations the study committee considers appropriate to improve the efficiency and economy of the administration of local government within the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(5): (3)(a)(iv); (5)(b); (5)(a); 17-52a-501
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(5)(a): (3)(a)(iv); (5)(b) If the study committee's report recommends a change in the form of county government, the study committee may conduct additional public hearings after filing the report under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(5)(b): (5)(a); 17-52a-501 Notwithstanding Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(5)(b)(i): that would recommend the adoption of an optional form different from that recommended in the original report; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(5)(b)(ii): 17-52a-501 within the 160-day period before the election under Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(6): Each meeting that the study committee holds shall be open to the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(7): If the study committee's report does not recommend a change in the form of county government, the report is final, the study committee is dissolved, and the process to change the county's form of government is concluded.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(8): The county legislative body shall provide for the study committee:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(8)(a): suitable meeting facilities;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(8)(b): necessary secretarial services;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(8)(c): necessary printing and photocopying services;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(8)(d): necessary clerical and staff assistance; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(8)(e): adequate funds for the employment of independent legal counsel and professional consultants that the study committee reasonably determines to be necessary to help the study committee fulfill its duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-403(9): The county legislative body may not interfere with the work of the study committee.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404 Contents of proposed optional plan.
--------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(1): 17-52a-303(1)(a)(ii); 17-52a-405(1)(a) The study committee or the sponsors of a petition described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(1)(a): 17-52a-405(1)(a) proposes the adoption of one of the forms of county government authorized in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(1)(b): contains detailed provisions relating to the transition from the existing form of county government to the form proposed in the optional plan, including provisions relating to the:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(1)(b)(i): election or appointment of officers specified in the optional plan for the new form of county government;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(1)(b)(ii): retention, elimination, or combining of existing offices and, if an office is eliminated, the division or department of county government responsible for performing the duties of the eliminated office;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(1)(b)(iii): continuity of existing ordinances and regulations;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(1)(b)(iv): continuation of pending legislative, administrative, or judicial proceedings;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(1)(b)(v): making of interim and temporary appointments; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(1)(b)(vi): preparation, approval, and adjustment of necessary budget appropriations;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(1)(c): specifies the date the optional plan becomes effective if adopted, which may not be earlier than the first day of January next following the election of officers under the new plan; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(1)(d): notwithstanding any other provision of this title and except with respect to an optional plan that proposes the adoption of the county commission or expanded county commission form of government, with respect to the county budget provides that:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(1)(d)(i): the county executive's role is to prepare and present a proposed budget to the county legislative body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(1)(d)(ii): the county legislative body's role is to adopt a final budget.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(2): (3) Subject to Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(3): 17-52a-503 An optional plan may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(3)(a): include any provision that is inconsistent with or prohibited by the Utah Constitution or any statute;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-52a-404(3)(b): specify compensation, including benefits, for any appointed or elected county official;

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-103 Unauthorized payment or warrant -- Investigation by another county attorney -- Action to enjoin or recover payment.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-103(1): (1)(a)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-103(1)(a): If a county officer, without authority of law, orders any money paid for any purpose, or if any other county officer draws a warrant in the officer's own favor or in favor of any other person without being authorized to do so by the county legislative body or by law, the county attorney of that county shall request a county attorney from another county to investigate whether an unauthorized payment has been ordered or an unauthorized warrant drawn.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-103(1)(b): (1)(a) If the county attorney requests a county attorney from another county to investigate under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-103(2): If an investigating county attorney determines that an unauthorized payment has been ordered or that an unauthorized warrant has been drawn, that county attorney may commence and prosecute an action in the name of the county:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-103(2)(a): if the payment has not been made or the warrant paid, to enjoin the payment of the unauthorized payment or of the unauthorized warrant; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-103(2)(b): if the payment has been made or the warrant paid, to recover from the payee or the county officer and the officer's official bondsman the amount paid.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-103(3): (2) An order of the county legislative body is not necessary in order to maintain an action under Subsection

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-105 Deposit of money in treasury.
-------------------------------------------------------------
Each officer who collects any money on behalf of the county shall as rapidly as it is collected deposit it into the county treasury.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106 Supervision of county elected officers -- Legislative body and executive may examine and audit accounts and conduct investigation.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106(1): As used in this section, "professional duties" means a county elected officer's functions, duties, and responsibilities specifically provided for by law and includes:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106(1)(a): the exercise of professional judgment and discretion reasonably related to the officer's required functions, duties, and responsibilities; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106(1)(b): the management of deputies and other employees under the supervision of the elected officer under statute or county ordinance, policy, or regulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106(2): (2)(a)(iv)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106(2)(a): A county legislative body and a county executive each:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106(2)(a)(i): may generally direct and supervise all elected county officers and employees to ensure compliance with general county administrative ordinances, rules, or policies;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106(2)(a)(ii): may not direct or supervise other elected county officers or their sworn deputies with respect to the performance of the professional duties of the officers or deputies;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106(2)(a)(iii): may examine and audit the accounts of all county officers having the care, management, collection, or distribution of money belonging to the county, appropriated to the county, or otherwise available for the county's use and benefit; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106(2)(a)(iv): may investigate any matter pertaining to a county officer or to the county or its business or affairs, and may require the attendance of witnesses and take evidence in any such investigation.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106(2)(b): (2)(a)(iv) In an investigation under Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106(2)(b)(i): the county executive or any member of the county legislative body may issue subpoenas and administer oaths to witnesses; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106(2)(b)(ii): if the county legislative body appoints members of the legislative body as a committee and confers on the committee power to hear or take evidence, the committee shall have the same power as the full county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-106(3): Nothing in this section may be construed to prohibit the county executive or county legislative body from initiating an action for removal or prosecution of an elected county officer as provided by statute.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-201 General powers, duties, and functions of county legislative body.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-201(1): Except as expressly provided otherwise in statute, each county legislative body shall exercise all legislative powers, have all legislative duties, and perform all legislative functions of the county, including those enumerated in this part.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-201(2): A county legislative body may take any action required by law and necessary to the full discharge of its duties, even though the action is not expressly authorized by statute.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-202 Eligibility -- Election.
--------------------------------------------------------
Each member of a county legislative body shall:Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-202(1): be a registered voter of the county which the member represents; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-202(2): have been a registered voter for at least one year immediately preceding the member's election.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-203 Chair -- Oaths -- Quorum.
---------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-203(1): Each county legislative body shall elect one of their number chair and may elect a vice chair.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-203(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-203(2)(a): The chair shall preside at all meetings of the county legislative body, and in case of the chair's absence or inability to act, the vice chair, if there is one, shall preside.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-203(2)(b): If both the chair and vice chair, if there is one, are absent or unable to act, the members present shall, by an order entered in their minutes, select one of their number to act as chair temporarily.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-203(3): Any member of the county legislative body may administer oaths to any person when necessary in the performance of official duties.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-203(4): Not less than a majority of members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and no act of the county legislative body shall be valid or binding unless a majority of members present when a quorum is present concurs therein.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-204 Meetings -- At county seat -- Exception.
------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-204(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-204(1)(a): The county legislative body shall provide by ordinance for the holding of regular meetings of the county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-204(1)(b): The county legislative body may cancel a regular meeting as the county legislative body considers appropriate.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-204(2): (2)(b)
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-204(2)(a): (2)(b) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-204(2)(b): If approved by a vote of the county legislative body, a county legislative body may hold an occasional meeting outside the county seat as the public business requires.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-205 Special meetings -- How called -- Business limited.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-205(1): If the business of the county requires a special meeting of the legislative body, such meeting may be ordered by a majority of the legislative body or by the chair.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-205(2): Each order calling a special meeting shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-205(2)(a): be signed by the members or chair calling the meeting;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-205(2)(b): be entered in the minutes of the legislative body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-205(2)(c): specify the business to be transacted at the meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-205(3): No business other than that specified in the order may be transacted at a special meeting unless all members of the county legislative body are present and give their consent.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-205(4): Except as otherwise provided by county ordinance, the county clerk shall give five days notice of each special meeting to each member of a county legislative body that does not join in the order calling the meeting.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206 Meetings to comply with open meetings law -- Records and minutes -- Compelling attendance at meetings of legislative body.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(1): As used in this section, "rules of order and procedure" means a set of rules that govern and prescribe in a public meeting:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(1)(a): parliamentary order and procedure;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(1)(b): ethical behavior; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(1)(c): civil discourse.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(2): Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act Each meeting of the county legislative body shall comply with
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(3): (3)(b); (3)(a)(i); (3)(a)(i); (3)(a); Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(3)(a)(i): adopt rules of order and procedure to govern a public meeting of the legislative body;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(3)(a)(ii): (3)(a)(i) conduct a public meeting in accordance with the rules of order and procedure described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(3)(a)(iii): (3)(a)(i) make the rules of order and procedure described in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(3)(a)(iii)(A): at each meeting of the county legislative body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(3)(a)(iii)(B): on the county's public website, if available.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(3)(b): (3)(a); Title 52, Chapter 4, Open and Public Meetings Act Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(4): The chair and clerk of the county legislative body shall sign the records and minutes of the county legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206(5): The legislative body of a county may compel the attendance of its own members at its meetings and provide penalties it considers necessary for the failure to comply with an exercise of the authority to compel attendance.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206.5 Expulsion of members prohibited -- Exception for disorderly conduct.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206.5(1): (2) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206.5(2): (3) Except as provided in Subsection
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206.5(2)(a): disorderly conduct at the open public meeting;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206.5(2)(b): a member's direct or indirect financial conflict of interest regarding an issue discussed at or action proposed to be taken at the open public meeting; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206.5(2)(c): a commission of a crime during the open public meeting.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-206.5(3): A governing body may adopt rules or ordinances that expand the reasons or establish more restrictive procedures for the expulsion of a member from a public meeting.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-207 Rules and regulations governing legislative body and transaction of business.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The county legislative body may make and enforce such rules and regulations for the government of itself, the preservation of order, and the transaction of business as may be necessary.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208 Ordinances -- Effective dates -- Publication -- Adoption of ordinances printed in book form -- Review of nuisance ordinances.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(1): The enacting clause of an ordinance adopted by the county legislative body shall be as follows: "The County Legislative Body of ______________County ordains as follows:".
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(2): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(2)(a): The chair of the county legislative body shall sign, and the county clerk shall attest to, each ordinance.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(2)(b): If the county legislative body votes to adopt an ordinance, county staff shall:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(2)(b)(i): record the vote of each county legislative body member in attendance and enter each vote in the minutes of the meeting; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(2)(b)(ii): enter the full text of the adopted ordinance in the county ordinance book.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(3): 45-1-101
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(3)(a): No ordinance passed by the county legislative body may take effect within less than 15 days after its passage.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(3)(b): 45-1-101 The county legislative body shall, before the ordinance may take effect:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(3)(b)(i): deposit a copy of the ordinance in the office of the county clerk; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(3)(b)(ii): 45-1-101
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(3)(b)(ii)(A): 45-1-101 publish a short summary of the ordinance, together with a statement that a complete copy of the ordinance is available at the county clerk's office and with the name of the members voting for and against the ordinance:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(3)(b)(ii)(A)(I): for at least one publication in:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(3)(b)(ii)(A)(I)(Aa): a newspaper published in and having general circulation in the county, if there is one; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(3)(b)(ii)(A)(I)(Bb): if there is none published in the county, in a newspaper of general circulation within the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(3)(b)(ii)(A)(II): 45-1-101 as required in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(3)(b)(ii)(B): post a complete copy of the ordinance in nine public places within the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(4): Any ordinance printed by authority of the county legislative body in book form or electronic media, or any general revision of county ordinances printed in book form or electronic media, may be adopted by an ordinance making reference to the printed ordinance or revision if a copy of the ordinance or revision is filed in the office of the county clerk at the time of adoption for use and examination by the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(5): If the county legislative body adopts an ordinance establishing rules and regulations, printed as a code in book form or electronic media, for the construction of buildings, the installation of plumbing, the installation of electric wiring, or other related or similar work, the county legislative body may adopt the ordinance by reference to the code book if a copy of the code book is filed in the office of the county clerk at the time of the adoption of the ordinance for use and examination by the public.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(6): If, in the opinion of the county legislative body, an ordinance is necessary for the immediate preservation of the peace, health, or safety of the county and the county's inhabitants, the ordinance may, if clearly stated in the ordinance, take effect immediately upon publication in one issue of a newspaper published in and having general circulation in the county, if there is one, and if there is none published in the county, then immediately after posting at the courthouse door.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(7): An ordinance may take effect at a later date than provided in this section, if the ordinance clearly states the later effective date.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-208(8): An order entered in the minutes of the county legislative body that an ordinance has been duly published or posted shall be prima facie proof of the publication or posting.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-209 Records to be kept.
---------------------------------------------------
The legislative body of each county shall cause to be kept:Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-209(1): a minute record, in which shall be recorded all orders and decisions made by the county legislative body and the daily proceedings had at all regular and special meetings;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-209(2): an allowance record, in which shall be recorded all orders for the allowance of money from the county treasury, to whom made and on what account, dating, numbering, and indexing the same through each year;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-209(3): a road record, containing all proceedings and adjudications relating to the establishment, maintenance, charge, and discontinuance of roads and road districts, and all contracts and other matters pertaining thereto;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-209(4): a franchise record, containing all franchises granted by the board, for what purpose, the length of time, and to whom granted, the amount of bond and license tax required or other consideration to be paid;
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-209(5): an ordinance record, in which shall be entered all ordinances or laws duly passed by the county legislative body; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-209(6): a warrant record, to be kept by the county auditor, in which shall be entered in the order of drawing all warrants drawn on the treasurer, with their number and reference to the order on the minute record, with date, amount, on what account, and the name of the payee.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-210 Dividing county into precincts and districts.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
A county legislative body may divide the county into precincts, districts, or other entities as permitted or required by law, and may change them and create others as convenience requires.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-211 Fees for services -- Exceptions.
----------------------------------------------------------------
The legislative body of each county shall adopt an ordinance or resolution that establishes fees for services provided by each county officer, except:Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-211(1): fees for the recorder, sheriff, and county constables; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-211(2): fees established by statute.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-212 Examination and audit of accounts.
------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-212(1): 17-36-3 As used in this section, "finance officer" means the same as that term is defined in Section
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-212(2): A county legislative body may examine and audit the accounts of all officers having the care, management, collection, or disbursement of money belonging to the county or appropriated by law or otherwise for its use and benefit.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-212(3): (3)(b)

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-212(3)(b): If a request for financial information requires an extended time period to research and compile, the finance officer of the county shall provide written notice to the legislative body that includes an explanation for the delay and the date when the information will be provided to the legislative body.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-212(4): A county legislative body may hire professional staff to provide technical assistance and analysis of all financial matters of the county.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-212(5): Chapter 19a, County Auditor Nothing in this section may be construed to affect a county auditor's authority under


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-213 Special funds.
----------------------------------------------
A county legislative body may establish a salary fund and such other county funds as it considers necessary for the proper transaction of the business of the county, and may transfer money from one fund to another as the public interest requires, except as otherwise specifically provided in statute.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-214 Seal for county.
------------------------------------------------
The legislative body of each county shall:Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-214(1): adopt a seal for the county, the impression of which shall contain the words "State of Utah, County of ________________"; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-214(2): file an impression of the seal in the office of the county clerk and with the Division of Archives.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-215 Seal for clerk of district court.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
If a county provides clerk services to that county's district court, the legislative body of the county shall:Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-215(1): provide a seal for the clerk of the district court of the county, the impression of which shall contain the words "District Court, State of Utah," together with the name of the county; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-215(2): file an impression of the seal in the office of the county clerk and with the Division of Archives.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216 Business license fees and taxes -- Application information to be transmitted to the county assessor.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(1): As used in this section, "business" means any enterprise carried on for the purpose of gain or economic profit, except that the acts of employees rendering services to employers are not included in this definition.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(2): Except as provided in Subsection (4), the legislative body of a county may by ordinance provide for the licensing of businesses within the unincorporated areas of the county for the purpose of regulation, and may impose fees on businesses to recover the county's costs of regulation.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(3): All license fees and taxes shall be uniform in respect to the class upon which they are imposed.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(4): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(4)(a): As used in this Subsection (4):
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(4)(a)(i): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(4)(a)(i)(A): "Event requirement" means a requirement a county imposes on individuals who participate in a county event.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(4)(a)(i)(B): "Event requirement" does not include a requirement that is inconsistent with Subsection (4)(b).
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(4)(a)(ii): "Exempt individual" means an individual who, under Subsection (4)(b), may not be required to have a business license or permit.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(4)(a)(iii): "County event" means an event hosted or sponsored by a county.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(4)(b): A county may notrequire a license or permit for a business that is operated:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(4)(b)(i): only occasionally; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(4)(b)(ii): by an individual who is under 19 years old.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(4)(c): Subsection (4)(b) does not prevent a county from imposing an event requirement on an exempt individual who participates in a county event.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(5): A county may not:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(5)(a): charge a license fee for a home based business unless the combined offsite impact of the home based business and the primary residential use materially exceeds the offsite impact of the primary residential use alone; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(5)(b): require, as a condition of obtaining or maintaining a license or permit for a business:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(5)(b)(i): that an employee or agent of a business complete education, continuing education, or training that is in addition to requirements under state law or state licensing requirements; or
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(5)(b)(ii): that a business disclose financial information, inventory amounts, or proprietary business information except as specifically authorized under state or federal law.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(6): The county business licensing agency shall transmit the information from each approved business license application to the county assessor within 60 days following the approval of the application.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-216(7): This section may not be construed to enhance, diminish, or otherwise alter the taxing power of counties existing prior to the effective date of Laws of Utah 1988,


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-217 Commanding services of sheriff.
---------------------------------------------------------------
A county legislative body may direct the sheriff to serve notices, subpoenas, citations, or other process issued by the legislative body, and to attend in person or by deputy all meetings of the legislative body to preserve order.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-218 Duties as board of equalization.
----------------------------------------------------------------
The legislative body of each county shall perform such duties as a county board of equalization as are provided by law.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-219 Auditor statement of county debt.
-----------------------------------------------------------------
The legislative body of each county shall have prepared by the auditor under its direction prior to the annual meeting for levying taxes a statement showing the indebtedness of the county, funded and floating, stating the amount of each class and the rate of interest borne by such indebtedness or any part of it.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-220 Taxation for county purposes.
-------------------------------------------------------------
A county legislative body may levy taxes upon the taxable property within the county for all county purposes.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-221 Tax for care, relief, and burial of indigents.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-221(1): (1)(a); (b) A county legislative body may, if it considers it necessary and expedient so to do, annually at its session at which the annual tax levy for county purposes is fixed and levied, assess and levy a tax for:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-221(1)(a): the care, maintenance, and relief of the indigent sick or dependent poor persons having a lawful settlement in the county;

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-221(1)(e): the salary of the county physician for attending the indigent sick or dependent poor and other duties as provided by law.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-221(2): (1) The taxes authorized under Subsection


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-222 Tax for exhibits encouraging trade.
-------------------------------------------------------------------
A county legislative body may levy a special tax on the taxable property within the county for the purpose of creating a fund to be used for collecting, preparing, and maintaining an exhibit of the products and industries of the county at any domestic or foreign exposition, fair, or livestock show for the purpose of encouraging immigration and increasing trade in the products of the state and for the purpose of maintaining, conducting, and furnishing facilities for livestock or other exhibitions or for the purpose of promoting and making water surveys, collecting data relating to the supply, distribution and use of water or the necessity for drainage or other reclamation work and the compilation of data or information to encourage the conservation of water for the reclamation of lands within the county or counties of the state either by the county or through the instrumentality of a corporation not for pecuniary profit, organized for that purpose.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-224 Rewards for information -- Law enforcement -- Protection of county property.
------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-224(1): 
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-224(1)(a): A county legislative body may appropriate funds from the county treasury for the offering and payment of rewards for information which directly assists in the enforcement of law and protection of county property.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-224(1)(b): The offering and payment of rewards shall be made under conditions and limitations as established by the county legislative body.

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-225 County legislative body may adopt Utah Procurement Code -- Retention of records.
----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-225(1): Title 63G, Chapter 6a, Utah Procurement Code A county legislative body may adopt any or all of the provisions of
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-225(2): Whenever any county is required by law to receive bids for purchases, construction, repairs, or any other purpose requiring the expenditure of funds, that county shall keep on file all bids received, together with proof of advertisement by publication or otherwise, for:
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-225(2)(a): at least three years following the letting of any contract pursuant to those bids; or

Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-226 Investigation by legislative body -- Witnesses -- Hearings.
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-226(1): A county legislative body may investigate any matter pertaining to the county or its business or affairs or any county officer, and may require the attendance of witnesses and take evidence in its investigations.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-226(2): At such investigations, any member of the county legislative body may administer oaths to witnesses.
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-226(3): If the county legislative body appoints a member of its body a committee upon any subject or matter and confers upon that member power to hear or take evidence, such committee shall have the same powers in the premises as the county legislative body itself.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-227 Breach of duty by county legislative body member -- Penalty.
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
A member of a county legislative body who, without just cause, refuses or neglects to perform a duty imposed upon the member or willfully violates any law governing the member as a member of the county legislative body, or who, as a county legislative body member, willfully, fraudulently, or corruptly attempts to perform an act unauthorized by law shall, in addition to the penalty provided in the criminal code:Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-227(1): forfeit to the county $500 for every such act, to be recovered on the member's official bond; and
Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-227(2): be further liable on the member's official bond to any person injured by the act for all damages sustained.


Utah Code Annotated § 17-53-228 Administrative hearings and procedures -- Penalty for code violation.
